I'll keep this short.

This game has amazing visuals, writing, and music and even a lot of fun and creative game play mechanics that actually make you think a lot of the time.

However, I must warn that this game is of a unique taste.

Simply put, you will have to put up with the fact you can do everything right or correctly in a run and still end up losing just because the enemies got lucky.

I really like when this game makes you think about runs and battles like puzzles to solve and I don't really like when the game becomes a needless slog to play or the outcome is purely dictated by RNG.

If you are willing to stomach the randomness on top of the deeply complex game play; then you will find this game to be a very rewarding and challenging experience.

If this doesn't sound appealing to you then I would still recommend giving the official soundtrack a listen to.

147549559.review:
As an avid board game player, I was really hoping this game would bridge the crunchy, meaningful decisions of a eurogame with the variety and character progression of a roguelike. Unfortunately, the decisions on offer are both highly restrictive and often devoid of meaning. 


In my opinion, the game's primary failing is its gaunt strategic horizon. Most of my runs end with a character who battles the boss in the exact same way that they battled the level 1 snowman. If we want to explore why this is the case, we would need to look at how a Dicey Dungeons character evolves over the course of a run. To my knowledge, there are three primary ways in which a character grows in power: max hp increases, max active dice, and item acquisition. 

A problem that immediately jumps to mind here is that the first two (hp and die count) are totally passive increases. They come simply from leveling up. So, for two thirds of the character growth in the game, there is no choice. A player cannot exchange these resources for others; they are simply acquired through killing monsters. This leaves players with a single axis along which they can craft their character: items. Don't get me wrong, this can work; but the items in the game would need to be highly varied and offered in substantial quantity. Unfortunately, this is far from the case.

To give one specific example of my frustration with the itemization, lets look at how items are triggered. Some items require specific die values, some require > or < values, and some require a large sum of dice added together. This is a great system. It sets the items apart and cleverly creates a demand for certain types of die values which are entirely contingent on your chosen items. Wonderful.

Tragically, the game fails to fully implement this system when it gives the player almost no control over their own dice economy. This means that if I have many items which require high sums, more dice and high rolls are something which highly favors my game plan. Dicey Dungeons is a game which does not allow me to seeks solutions to the demands of my strategy. And, this just strikes me as true: a game which does not allow me to engineer my own strategies is a game which is not fun.

As it stands, I have no way of ensuring I receive high rolls or additional dice - and this the game's primary failure: it is simply impossible to flesh out a strategy in the current state of the game. It's very frustrating that I can look at my items and know which types synergies I'd like to add to my pool while also knowing that my chances of being offered even a single synergistic item in the future is very low. I simply cannot meaningfully craft a strategy with so few tools at my disposal. The game, whether intentionally or not, implicitly commands the player to shut-up and roll. Talk of strategy and dice economy is not to be had. Take what you're given and shove it in the slots. A player's job seems to be limited to determining the proper order in which they place their dice and nothing beyond.



The game suffers from other significant design flaws like overly-long, trivial fights, deterministic turns (turns which can be played in a single way and in which player decision has no impact), poor item balance, lack of enemy variety, heals which come primarily through leveling, etc; but, make no mistake, the central issue remains the lack of control over your itemization. 

These issues combine to create a game filled with menial turns in which simply finding a use for my dice, rather than agonizing between uses for my dice, is the norm. Moments like, "Oh, I rolled a 2. That's not ideal. Oh well. I guess I'll just shove it in the slot anyway." are extremely common as is having too many dice or too few. There is nothing which the player can do to curtail these frustrating inefficiencies. They are simply a byproduct the inelegant design.

Differing design approaches found in popular board games might have been better suited to the task of creating a strategically interesting dice-based roguelite. For instance, I could see the addition of different colored dice, a dice draft system, dice-forging (where you remove certain pip values from dice), coupled with a more fleshed out economic progression system adding a lot of intrigue to combat in this game. However, as it stands, Dicey Dungeon's decisions are just not interesting to me and I think the game fails to deliver on its enticing premise.

146538124.review:
What we have here is an interesting little game with cool and to a certain degree innovative gameplay mechanics.
Going by the title and the premise you could think that this is a game that is merely based on luck, but it's much more than that. Clever planning how to set up your character is very important. There is an enormous amount of possibilites when it comes to strategies because every character (and there are six of them) has a completely different playstyle - it's like playing a different game each time you choose another character. Furthermore there are lots of abilities that can be gained through leveling up, opening chests and buying them at stores (the thief can even steal abilities from enemies which is a lot of fun, especially since stealing one ability transformed my thief into a whole other character that is not one of the six characters eligible in the menu which I found hilarious). To add on top of the already relatively large pool of abilities: every ability can be upgraded so that its effects change.
As you can see there is a lot of experimenting involved in this game and because the characters special skills are adjusted to the different scenarios that can be selected after you chose a character there is a constant need for new strategies.
The only downsides of this game that are worth mentioning are personal ones: the art style wasn't one of my favorites and for my ears the music was awful...but that's because I have never been into this kind of music as it comes with heavy "mood-debuffs" for me :P Maybe there are people out there with a similar taste in music that want to consider that (then again you could always turn off the music and play you own music tracks in the background instead). Probably it's completely fine for a lot of other people though...and I have the feeling they put a lot of love in the character, enemy and environmental level design (4 hours in and it seemed very diversified). 
All in all it's a pleasant experience and a well designed game that absolutely deserves to be recommended.

146030236.review:
The game seriously lacks depth. With one or two runs per character you'll have seen pretty much every combo and item they can do. 

The enemies are fine but, harder scenarios make some enemies completely anti-fun. For example, one enemy hides the value of all of your dice. How are you supposed to do any strategy or thinking if you can't see anything that you rolled? Another enemy prevents you from using your character's unique ability if it rolls doubles and I've never once seen it not roll doubles. Where's the fun in that? That enemy takes away any uniqueness the character has. Is that 'fun'? 

Scenarios beyond the first usually require save-scumming to avoid having to play the scenario hundreds of times hoping for perfect roles. There's literally no counter-play to some bosses, you just have to hope they roll poorly. Some scenarios give you interesting mechanics but parallel world really shows you how limited in depth the game is when you get *all* new equipment and it feels very much the same as before. 

Art style is nice. The dialogue is essentially the same joke dozens of times: "You might win but, aww you didn't". Same with enemies, they all just say how great it is to fight you or make a noise.

Wish this game had a draw mechanic rather than a backpack. Your inventory is enormous and you literally can't fill half of it in any scenario even if you never sell anything. 

If it's on sale, go for it. For full price this isn't worth $15.

145784020.review:
Dicey dungeons:
LO BUENO:
 agradable de jugar
 fácil de entender
 complejidad y profundidad media-baja
 adictivo durante las 12 primeras horas
LO MALO:
 tiene rejugabilidad pero es limitada, nada que ver con un Slay The Spire, FTL o Darkest dungeon.
 progresión muy lenta basada en desbloqueos progresivos, de 1 en 1.
 Falta de variedad en los equipos y en los enemigos, con lo que pasadas las 12 primeras horas empiezas a tener sensación de que falta algo.

Dicey dungeons es un híbrido deckbuilder/colocación de dados decente. Es fácil ponerse con él, es divertido y adictivo al principio, y realmente te engancha y disfrutas descubriendo los nuevos personajes y probando combos. Da para unas cuantas horas muy muy divertidas hasta que, debido a su falta de variabilidad en los mapas, enemigos y cartas(equipos), acaba provocando una sensación de repetición y se te va la addicción... Aún así, las mecánicas son divertidas(es un hibrido entre deckbuilder y colocación de dados) y sería injusto decir que no sobresale del montón. A mi entender, está entre el bien y el notable y merece mucho su compra, en rebajas, por 5-6€.

Para amantes de los deckbuilders mas intensos/profundos/complejos probad con el archifamoso Slay The Spire o el menos conocido pero muy digno Fate Hunter.

[h2] Review at 44hours of play [/h2]
So after 2 months and completed 3 other games from the last review, I went back to this game. Again the rng is so screwed up but I managed to complete all 36 episodes with 24 failure in the Witch elimination stage. I finally started to see a few thing about the game. Here's a few tips for those who are still struggling:

1. Return to title if you started a match with almost full hp but the fight rng is not in your favour
2. Change your deck or go to a store or something before heading back to the fight. This reset the stage. If you head back to the fight, you will get the same dice rolls and unfavorable rng.
3. With the reset, you can win the fight after multiple attempt but this method is really testing on your patience too.

Again, my review does not change and I do not recommend this game unless you have the patience to sit through weeks and months of not clearing a single stage. 

Try this game at your own risk.

145391765.review:
Dicey Dungeons is a fantastic rogue-like game filled with all the associated joy of having a good run come together, and anguish at Lady Luck just not going your way.

You can play as 6 different die, (yes the die ARE the characters), as they venture their way through the underworld, which has a very Undertalesque vibe to the humour and characters imo. All 6 playable characters have distinguishable play-styles that offers you a variety of experiences. Classic tropes such as Warrior, Thief, Wizard (witch) are all here, with a few different classes to shake up your expectations (the inventor, robot, and jester). Like any other rogue-like, seeds are randomly generated upon initiating a game, and you venture through the underworld fighting enemies, opening chests, encountering shops and traders, and upgrades.

Combat is turn based, and your resources are your skills and your number of dice. All characters begin with just 2 dice, but as you level up, you gain additional dice. The dice are randomly drawn at turn start and you must use what Lady Luck gives you to overcome your foes. 

The game ranges from easy to borderline unfair, it can depend on your runs, and of course... your dice rolls. Despite the larger emphasis on Luck in this game than in other games of its ilk, such as Slay the Spire, you can still sort of get to a consistent state of winning more than you lose. I typically win 3-4 for every loss, with the exception of using the Witch and Inventor, who I roughly have a 50-50 win streak with. 

It's a highly addictive game that I recommend people to give a chance. There's little story, but the gameplay loop makes up for it, and I've had a blast with it. 

And if you run out of things to do, there are bonus levels made by the devs, as well as a modding community to add characters and items.

Estimated Game Length for any%: 10-20 hours (yes it is that wide of a range)
Estimated Game Length for 100%: 30+ hours
Score: 8/10
Recommended Value: $10-15

145339900.review:
I haven't enjoyed a game this much in a long time. A brief description of gameplay: puzzle-like mechanics in a turn-based dungeon crawler, technically a "roguelike" in that you do make individual runs through randomly generated dungeons that can have different layouts/loot each time, and then start over new when/if you die. But there's also a loose story and a lot of fun background detail that flesh it out, as well as lots of different modes to play. Overall very smooth gameplay and graphics (I played it on my Steam Deck with no issues, and it shifted very comfortably between touch screen and controller whenever I needed it to). But most importantly, fun mechanics that are challenging in a "make you think about this in new ways" sort of way (rather than "artificially difficult/grindy for the sake of dragging this out" kind of way). Two main standouts that make this game amazing, in my opinion:

1. The writing. I expected this type of title to be very tropey and gimmicky which... it is? But it's very self-aware and manages to push right up against the fourth wall without breaking it entirely. Masterful use of running gags, and the best set up/payoff joke I've seen since Community's Beetlejuice stunt. More importantly, it manages to convey a whole lot - story progression, world building, character building - through small clippets of dialogue without any actual cutscenes or animations, and although there is a lot of repeated dialogue, it's mixed in well enough with unique situational/character-based dialogue that even on my last run of the game, I was still seeing new things.

2. The mechanics. A lot of roguelikes or dungeon crawlers will boast "x different classes to choose from!" and then you end up using the same strategies or gear combination on all of them because the essential gameplay remains the same. Not so with Dicey Dungeons - you'll find yourself having to shift your strategy even on the same character, depending on the episode you choose or even sometimes in the same episode based on some randomized mechanic factors. Even more amazingly, though, the mechanics manage to be complex and varied (fresh and fun) *without* being overly complicated or unnecessarily difficult. RNG can screw you over but there's almost always a way to prevent it from doing so, if you're paying attention. 

In conclusion, there's a reason I logged 100 hours in this game up to completion / at time of this review, and it's not because the game was grindy, tedious, unnecessarily difficult, or overly idle. It's one of the few games I would genuinely revisit even after completing 100%. Do give it a go - even at full price it would be a bargain but I managed to snag my copy in a Humble Bundle and it's a frequent flyer in sales and bundles so there's really no reason not to pick it up. :)

"Most gamblers quit before their big win."

SCORE: 8/10 

REVIEW: 

Dicey Dungeons presents a captivating fusion of tabletop luck-based elements and the allure of a roguelike deckbuilder. This unique blend offers a refreshingly innovative experience where even repeated story runs yield significantly diverse outcomes.

However, it's worth noting that some missions within the game can prove astonishingly challenging, occasionally bordering on soul-crushing difficulty. This sentiment comes from someone who boasts a conservative thousand hours spent within the genre. Despite this, I eagerly anticipate the potential for a sequel in the form of Dicey Dungeons 2, should the developer choose to embark on that journey.

The game's pricing strikes a harmonious balance. With the capacity to provide approximately 30-40 hours of gameplay without significant content repetition, it delivers a satisfying value proposition. Nonetheless, one area where the experience appears to fall short is in the domain of build diversity. This aspect could use some enhancement in order to align more cohesively with the essence of a deckbuilding game.

On the whole, if you have an inclination for card games or the thrill of games of chance, Dicey Dungeons promises an enjoyable venture. However, due to its formidable difficulty, the game might not serve as the most inviting introduction for newcomers to the genre.

142896244.review:
Dicey Dungeons is a roguelike where you roll dice, gain abilities and allocate said dice to use your abilities. 

The game is pretty straightforward in its premise but with a mix of 6 differing characters that switch up how the game is played as well as 6 levels for each (With varying rules) there's a lot here to keep the game from feeling too repetitive. Now, if we were rating the game based on characters, the majority are fine with some variance in difficulty. Witch however is a pock mark on the otherwise great characters. 

Aesthetically the game is delightful both in terms of visuals, effects and sound and music. All of it fits and it's all well done. For such a simple overall game the actual content and polish present is incredibly high. 

The difficulty is reasonably fair (Unless you're playing Witch) with each character and their levels varying in challenge. Most of the time I was able to win runs on my first attempt due to smart planing and usage of character abilities and items. The game doesn't feel particularly unfair or weighed in the player or enemies favour which is great. 

Overall a solid title with a tonne of content and charm. Worth the price of admission but if you're on the fence pick it up on a sale. You wont be disappointed.

142766308.review:
A mix of tabletop and video game dice-based RPG combat. It has a cast of cute dice themed characters with some innovative mechanics and a variety of missions to go on. Unfortunately the missions are the same every time which feels counter to the whole RNG gameplay design - especially since the levels feel set up to mimic roguelite dungeons.

The only thing that changes are your dice rolls as you try to grind your way from start to finish meaning that your success is just... hoping for good numbers. There are decisions to be made but the tactics feel undermined by the reliance on RNG to get anywhere. I've played the game so many times now and while it was a lot of fun to start with it quick grew stale from the repetition of knowing whats coming and that I don't really have much control over how far I get.

A creative endeavour, good for a few playthroughs that ended up feeling too samey in the wrong places.

This game is great and the only game I've really 100% in regards to challenges and gameplay. Here are some of my favorite things about it.

Music is great and actually what prompted me to write this review. I completed this game a while ago, but stumbled upon the music on youtube. Listening to the soundtrack brought me back to how much fun I had with this game. All of the music is on point. Its a cool mix of jazzy techno beats. Boss themes are a bop. 

Art style is charming and unique. The enemies designs are memorable and fit the aesthetic very well. Squid baby for life. The characters really have their own identities. The Witch makes my brain hurt. 

Gameplay is heavy roguelike elements with the fun of dice manipulation. It really feels like you're rolling the dice with every decision you make. It is different enough to stand out amongst the other games I have played. 

Overall, this is a game i truly recommend. I've never really written a review for a game before but this game really deserves all the love it gets. Not to mention the added bonus content after the fact. (halloween, reunion, etc). I hope there is a Dicey Dungeons 2 at some point, but who knows.

TLDR: 100% complete. 100% fun. 100% get it.

Pros: 

- Baller OST; very catchy and has been stuck in my head for awhile
- Interesting mechanics, especially when the modifiers start kicking in, fun to learn. 

Cons:

- Aside from modifiers that the game adds later on to every run, each dungeon run feels very similar. There isn't a lot of diversity of enemies or cards, both of which are heavily utilized in runs.

- I'm all for hard and luck-based games, but  lucky runs are few and far between and you need those in order to beat some of the harder challenges. It's pretty frustrating because you can make every right move and still get shafted. I've played games where I get shafted like Darkest Dungeon and I feel less bad. 

Basically: If on sale for around $5, it's worth a shot. If not, pass.

141934383.review:
This is the most tepid thumbs up I can give. Dicey Dungeons is a a decently fun dice-rolling roguelite that has some UI and usability issues.  Each character is unique and plays entirely different, which is a huge plus. The map node system is a bit limited, but usable. The problems I mainly have are two fold:

1) Lack of description - before you play a couple of battles and puzzle things out with each character, you literally have no idea what some of them do. In addition, some of the abilities you get are quite vague. Split a dice? What does it split into? Combine dice? What does that do? (in the end, it's literally just split or combine the dice into random dice)
2) Lack of usability, especially with the Witch. When you're in a battle, your spellbook only displays the names of your spells, but not what they do.  

Dicey Dungeons ultimately is a fun enough game, but couldn't keep my attention for long.

141895344.review:
This is not the type of Rougelike that you are going to play just for the sake of doing a run for fun, this games replayability excels the best for people who like completing games to full 100 percent. This is mostly due to the fact that each run does not feel that much different from each other in the grand scheme, let me explain.

The only truly random thing about this game is the dice aspect, the enemies you will encounter and the gimmick of each character. The dungeon layout, the items you find in chests and shops are mostly the same and have a rather small pool to get from.

A small pool does not automatically mean its boring, it does allow you for better strategesizing in the long run, in theory.

At the start of a run, in a chest, or when you level up most characters you will get to choose in some way between multiple cards with a different status gimmick in most of the episodes. This however locks you in to only get cards from chests and shops with the same status gimmick that you chose (There are also cards without a status gimmick that can still appear just fine). There is a small chance you will find different status cards, a freeze card even if you chose fire for example, I noticed, but they are usually on the weaker side.

This creates a problem of instead choosing the card gimmick that you feel like currently using for fun, you are instead choosing to lock into the card gimmick that will help you against a specific enemy in the future.

No matter how fun poison is, since no enemy has it as its weakness and 3 very annoying enemies even have it as a resistance, choosing to have these cards in battle just makes your run harder for no reason. Fire and Ice help against two very annoying and strong potential enemies lategame and the absence of these items is very noticable. This makes runs feel very repetetive at times if you are looking to maximize your chance at winning.

This makes the game very hard. You will not be able to prepare for the strong ice enemies if you chose ice cards yourself, which will make feel losing is outside of your control especially with the dice aspect. Prepare to lose a ton without literally being able to do anything against it just because you got unlucky with enemy encounters.

However despite these issues the game manages to feel very fresh if you do beat episodes.

Every character has a very unique gimmick that feels different from each other, and every epsiode from every character manages to keep their gameplay unique with interesting rules, it manages to give it a different take on their playstyle every single time, basically having 36 different ways to play plus 1-6 more if you count the final boss. This is why completionists will have most fun of this game, being "forced" to beat every episode will make the next one way more fun, and since this game is very hard you will take quite some time trying to do so.

All in all its a very fun game and worth your money, but if you are looking for replayability look somewhere else.

It's just fun!

140334032.review: Nice art style. Simple and addictive mechanics. After the introductory stages there are some increasingly difficult challenges where there is no guarantee that sound strategy will get you to the end. After multiple runs where my carefully crafted engines of mathmatical mayhem are undone by a few bad dice rolls. Thus the tragic flaw of the run-based game reveals itself. Without the social elements of a real-life deck building game, and without any sort of story or meta-progression to build towards some bigger goals there is nothing to lessen the sting of a run gone bad. There is merely the simple return to the character select screen and the question "what did I accomplish in the last hour?" If you can take this kind of frustration in stride then you are a better person than I, but if, like me, you have become spoiled by run-based games that give you something more to strive for then this game is quite skippable. It is a solid representation of its milieu, but dares not to strive for anything more grand.

139806280.review:
[h1]Let's spin the wheel yet again![/h1]
A creative and colorful roguelike dice-building game with six different characters, each with their unique playstyle. Although luck is thematically placed front and center in this game, most matches don't feel cheaped out by RNG, as tactics such as risk management and number manipulation help alleviate a lot of would-be luck-related grievances.

Not only that, but the design of both the enemies and the cards allow for really inventive play with the dice received each round, estimulating a "work-with-what-you've-been-dealt" mentality that takes a lot of frustration out of the game and makes each round more or less independent from the rest, increasing the information fog and reducing analysis paralysis, which is something I really appreciate.

139716155.review:
It's hard to overstate how much of a missed-opportunity this game's theme is. To differential from other Slay The Spire impersonators, Dicey Dungeons is presented as a game show.  

But there's no trivia or word games, no audience participation or mini-games of any kind; everything is battles and shops. The achievements aren't presented as prizes (they're enemy cards) and even the 'episodes' (which serve as increasing difficulty levels) feature no differentiating motif. Outside of the introduction, Dicey Dungeons feels more like a dungeon crawl and less like a game show.

It's fortunate that the gameplay is so solid. The classes all feature distinct strategies and the more complex ones are brilliantly designed. And despite the name, the game features less RNG than most games of this type. And the runs take about an hour to complete; a sweet spot where finishing a run in one go feels satisfying but not taxing. 

It's just a shame they didn't fit the theme with the design or presentation.

138999987.review:
I like Dicey Dungeons! HOWEVER, I think there are some important caveats one should know before going in.

First off, Dicey Dungeons is NOT a roguelike. Well, not really anyway. It is more like a puzzle game in a roguelike skin. Yes, you get to choose cards and upgrades as you go, but ultimately each scenario will only have one or two "correct" builds. This is not a game you can replay infinitely; once you've beaten a challenge, that's pretty much it.

Second, make sure you don't mind learning new mechanics, because this game has a lot of them. I think the reason it's not a "real" roguelike, is the (in my opinion rather questionable) decision to make their ascension mode, rather a mode that adds more difficulty modifier as the ascension level increases, just an entirely new class for each level. This leads to a lot of breadth gameplay wise, but not a lot of depth, as making the classes fleshed out would basically mean doing that a ridiculous number of times since every difficulty level is basically its own class. 

Third, some of the challenges are bullshit. Like really dumb. Most of them I beat in 1 or 2 attempts, but a few of them are either really difficult, or straight up require you to get reeeeeally lucky to win.

With all that said, Dicey Dungeons is an absolute blast to play. As a cardgame and roguelike enthusiast, it offered something I've never seen: incredibly entertaining and deep battling segments. In most roguelike cardbattlers, the battles are actually the the most dull part. In a game like StS, most of the strategy comes into play in the drafting portion. If the enemy is attacking, and you have a shielding card, you play the shielding card. Obviously it goes a bit deeper than that, but the point is, generally, you don't need to put much thought into it. Dicey Dungeons on the other hand has you doing *so* much in a turn, and it always feels like if you spent crunching the numbers just a bit longer, you could've come up with an even better solution. Yeah, it's literally dice rolls, but rolling a bad number in this game never feels nearly as punishing as drawing a bad hand in other roguelikes, where a bad hand can be the difference between life and death. I certainly would have liked a true roguelike with a huge diversity of builds and whatnot, but for what it is, Dicey Dungeons is great. And a great value for the price.

138707761.review:
Dicey Dungeons sands down the "rogue-lite" genre into a friendly, approachable casual affair while having the cunning and creativity of the genre's best. Somewhere between Yahtzee and Hearthstone - but more fun than both - our plucky, cubic heroes must descend the six levels of the dungeons over and over, until the time finally comes to confront Lady Luck herself - in a cheerfully sadistic game show watched across the world.

The core gameplay is simple. In the first battle, each turn you have a number of dice; slot a die into your sword to deal the die's number of damage to your opponent. Your other ability, Combat Roll, lets you reroll a die, and can be used three times per turn. So what do you do? Use Combat Roll to reroll until you get a high value - but don't get too greedy! - and deal the most damage you can. As you progress you will find equipment with other effects, like status effects, or chopping your dice into smaller values. That equipment might have conditions, like only accepting dice lower than 4, or a matching pair of dice. You manipulate the dice you are given for the best result each turn. The game is more interested in strategy and dice puzzles than luck, so losing very rarely feels like the game's fault. That simple, solid gameplay foundation means you never feel lost, even as the game departs further and further from what you know.

The six playable classes all have wildly different gameplay, thanks to their unique equipment and abilities - the Warrior has his Combat Roll, but the Thief can use enemies' equipment, for example. There are six levels per class, lasting around 20 minutes each: level 1 is a simple class introduction; levels 2 and 3 impose a bizarre condition, and you typically win by discovering that level's gimmick equipment; level 4 is level 1 with stronger enemies. Level 5, amazingly, takes place in a parallel universe where all the equipment you are familiar with is thrown out of the window - oh, and all the status effects work differently. Level 6 is more like a typical rogue-lite; it plays like level 1 but each floor, a random new rule is imposed which generally makes the game tougher for you. Level 6 gives the game the most replay value, as it is influenced by the equipment set you choose at the start, including some "hard mode" equipment. The final boss is a new kind of strategising you have never had to do previously. Two DLCs of about six levels each were made; Halloween Special is a series of head-scratching puzzles and Reunion is... yet another equipment overhaul! Barring a horrible difficulty spike in Witch level 4, which I navigated by abusing the ability to quit on the game over screen, the game is exceedingly casual and you can expect to breeze through many levels first try. For more challenge, you can go for all achievements, and you'll notice a few things you can attempt just for bragging rights, like the mighty Omnislash. I've completed all main levels and am satisfied for now, but I know that the game is so easy to pick up and play that I'll have no problems coming back and relearning it when I want more.

If I haven't convinced you how much this game should appeal to casual players, simply look at the presentation. The game loads in seconds and starts almost as quickly. A minimal number of huge UI elements mean everything you need is right in your face when you need it. Bright colours and chunky sprites abound in an art style I think of as Charlie and Lola meets Dungeons and Dragons. Every animation is super-satisfying, from the way your equipment slams into the enemy's face, to the way the wizard magicks his socks off and back on again. Every piece of equipment is explained intuitively in just a few words. You go first and can even see your enemy's equipment and play around it. There's virtually no ambiguity over rules and no chance of making an input error, unless you're rushing. My only criticism is that sometimes you need a lot of dice on screen, and as more and more dice appear they obstruct your input, so how to display many dice could have been rethought. Creator Terry Cavanagh has again joined forces with the mighty Chipzel, who has provided an OST of wall-to-wall earworms bursting with vigour and attitude (even the low-health sound is a good listen). Dialogue is almost always friendly and positive, with a clearly British bent and some good laughs to be had. You might notice a somewhat small roster of enemies, but it's good to get familiar with them, their equipment can vary and the class you play changes how scary they are to play against.

You can always count on Cavanagh to produce something brilliant, and Dicey Dungeons is one of his best. Exemplary game design, great balancing for casual gaming with some room for challenge, and a vibrant personality. I strongly recommend Dicey Dungeons to anyone after a solid time-killer, especially on Steam Deck or smartphone and even more if you have headphones.

138195476.review:
Despite the amount of time playing this game, I have to give this game a legitimately negative review. Not a joke "haha bad review because it took my life away". An actual bad review.

It's a fun enough game, but so much of the design choices are bafflingly obtuse and don't seem to rear their ugly heads until after you've done a few runs. Difficulty is almost entirely because battles are one sided and enemies have an absolute boatload of HP. Whereas you might be blessed to find an attack that does D+2 damage, or even x2, it almost always comes with a negative (Max 5, or deals damage to you, or requires a big investment of dice, or)

This by itself is fine. In fact, aside from the HP Sponges that enemies tend to be, it's FUN. But the problem is it relies on the "The odds are stacked against you" kind of difficulty, which results in either blowing through encounters, hitting a wall...or breezing through and THEN hitting a wall suddenly. Because some enemies have unfun abilities that counter everyone completely. One enemy, the Loud Bird, is designed so that it can literally ALWAYS do 2 attacks. One weakens you (negatively affects your attacks), one gives it Dodge (allows it to ignore an attack), and another silences you (you cannot use your special power...and in the case of the Wizard, you can't add new spells). The bird gets 4 d6 to draw from, and it needs doubles for silence, evens for one and odds for the other.

I'll save you the math. There's a 72% chance it can do all three things. The other option is "Only 2 things".
This is not uncommon. Lots of enemies have powers that seems unreasonable. I won't say the luck itself is rigged, but the options to deal with the enemies dice rolls are few and far between, usually trading damage for special effects.

The game has a really strong core and is just fun enough to stave off the bitterness, but under the surface it's a fundamentally unfair game that stacks FAR too much in the opponents favor, and far too little ever in yours.

to sum up: Not a bad game, but deeply flawed one that might not be worth full price.

136655868.review:
Took me about 71.2 hours for a full completionist run (all achievements in the main game *and* Halloween + Reunion DLCs).

Dicey Dungeons starts out as a charming, relaxing, gentle RPG and evolves into an addictingly strategic game that - despite being torturous - will have you coming back for more. With levels that range from journeys not requiring too much brain power to mind-boggling brain teasers that'll have you sitting at your computer for cumulative hours trying to figure them out, I believe Dicey Dungeons truly has something for everyone interested in the genre. I'm not usually a fan of anything that labels itself as a "roguelike", but the battle system truly adds gravitas to each fight as you develop favorite and least favorite characters (that damned Vacuum...), and it encourages the player to dust themselves off and pick themselves back up again upon their defeat because there's plenty of different strategies you can try if yours didn't work on the first go (and, of course, there's an aspect of randomness involved that can certainly contribute to a lost run).

I don't know if I've ever legitimately 100%'d a game in my life until this point, but I was not able to put this game down until I did.

136446680.review:
NOTE: This review covers the main game and some of the Halloween bonus content, NOT the Reunion DLC. There will, however, be no spoilers. This review was made after completing the main story.

Premise/Story: You play as one of 6 contestants on the titular game-show hosted by the malevolent Lady Luck, the personification of all random chance. By making it through the dungeons on the show, the contestants have a "chance" to earn their worldly desires, or be further stuck in the dungeons as a walking dice-person. Find a way out of the show, and if there's a way to best Lady Luck herself. 
Every character, be it dice, minion, or evil force of rigged rolls, are brimming with personality and charm thanks to the quick & snappy game-show like banter. While it's not the most complex or profound story, it's certainly a fun story to watch unfold.

Gameplay: Dicey Dungeons is a mini-roguelike (runs take 20-30 minutes rather than 60+) RPG with a heavy focus on luck-based mechanics. Each contestant has 6 episodes, or levels, culminating in a finale. Each episode consists of making it down through 5 floors of enemies, and beating the boss at the end. Sounds simple, but this game will not make it easy. Each contestant has a different way of playing the game that brings a different flavor of challenge to the table (some flavors are more palatable than others), and each episode can offer a different experience as well. 

Contestants will always start with the same equipment (unless playing episodes 5 & 6), and also have a Limit Break (Yes that's what it's called), a special ability that recharges upon taking damage. Episodes from each contestant follow this format: 
1: Standard Rules
2 & 3: A gimmick add-on that slightly changes the gameplay
4: The Elimination Round, where all enemies have upgraded equipment.
5: Parallel Universe, where all status effects and equipment function differently.
6: Bonus Round. You start with some equipment and standard rules, but each new floor adds a new rule to deal with.
Battles with enemies are turn-based, and involve you and the opponent taking turns rolling dice and matching them to the equipment you have. The diversity of the equipment allows for a lot of different builds to form, as well as a lot of hair-pulling moments when the dice just don't roll in your favor. While this gameplay loop is satisfying for the most part, the biggest negative I have might just be a skill issue on my end: The Witch's mechanics aren't as fun as the rest of the quirky cast. Some enemies play fast and loose with their equipment, and can easily shut down the Witch's mandatory setup time, especially if you don't have their Limit Break ready. However, every other character is stupidly fun, my personal favorite being the Robot. Even if you aren't playing as the distinctly hardest character in the game, it can sometimes be really annoying to have a string of losses when it was going so well (like the bosses suddenly rolling exactly what they need to screw you over after a 20-30 minute run), but if you want to look on the bright side, it does technically play into the story.

Visuals/Music: Not much to say here. The artstyle is perfectly cartoony in all aspects, serving to make characters more expressive and eye-catching. The music is done by Chipzel, and my god is it done well. The battle themes, especially for bosses, have that big-band jazzy feel that's reminiscent of certain gameshow themes like The Price is Right or Family Feud. "Swing Me Another 6" and "Tempting Fate" are especially bangers.

Completion: Achievements are mostly unlocked by either playing through the game normally, or by doing some task that only a certain contestant can maybe do in a run. By doing these achievements, you earn bios of the various minions you take on in the dungeons, fleshing out their own personalities with fun little queries like "Karaoke Go-To" or "Greatest Fear". This also happens in the Halloween Bonus Content with the new enemies that show up in there.

Conclusion: This game's surprisingly packed with content for the cheap price tag. I bought this when it was on sale and I definitely feel like I made out with a bargain. If you don't like luck-based games, you will despise this one. However, if you enjoy a bit of risk in your day-to-day gaming life, then buy it, and just roll with it.

Close call on this one.

I think Circadian Dice and One Deck Dungeon are both better games in the genre.  This one is a bit less interesting, and features many characters which are either slow & tedious to play, or just very fluky and annoying (or both).  Combine that with runs that are too long individually, and you often get frustrating experiences and time waste. The 'naive' art and 'humorous' tone/art also get old very very fast.

On the upside, it's technically sound and there are interesting mechanics.  If you are a fan of the genre and liked the two games mentioned above. This might is probably worth your time.

135194566.review:
Dicey Dungeons is a fantastic game that offers a unique blend of turn-based combat, rogue-like gameplay, and card game mechanics (though the last one is a bit of a spoiler). The game's primary gameplay mechanic involves using dice rolls to activate equipment, each with their own unique effects.

However, the game is not simply a matter of rolling high to win and low to lose. Success depends more on equipping items that combo with each other and lead you to success independent of your rolls - some items are especially focused on only dice manipulation.

The game features six playable characters, each with their own unique playing style and a special limit break move. There are six episodes to play through, each with different rules that change the gameplay - so you get 36 challenges total.

The game's colourful art style and wacky enemy designs add to the overall charm of the game, even though in the beginning I saw it as cheap, it really grew on me.

It's not a hard game, but sometimes it can be, and also it seems that it's very unfair on purpose, there are enemies that needs high numbers and they ALWAYS get that high numbers on dices. The randomize generation of numbers are not always random, like if the game had a porcentage inclination of dices on certain enemies, this can be much more remarkable on hard mode, wich with a few characters is insanely hard to beat all enemies, so the game forces you to choose what enemies to fight, but this limits to get your max health or other rewards. What I really enjoyed was the final boss, very creative and fun, and also perfectly balanced. 

So, if you enjoy this kind of games, don't hesitate and buy it, will grant you a bunch of hours and fun.

134329475.review:
There's quite a bit of content and the game can be very engaging, but the main downside is the luck aspect. Sometimes you feel like you had no chance of winning, due to the enemy rolling multiple 6's and doing half your health in a single turn, while you rolled all ones and did next to no damage. You can try to build around consistency to avoid this, but no matter how hard you try, there is always the chance that you get screwed over. Even though that seems bad, otherwise the game is pretty dang good, so get it on sale if it seems up your alley.
Edit: I have beaten the game. In order to reach the ending, you must win at least 5 runs with each character - meaning 30 winning runs overall. I learnt that you could abuse the game a bit by just hitting back to menu if your in a fight and its going wrong to completely redo said fight. The ending was pretty dang disappointing, but I think the final run you have to do to get said ending was pretty good. Overall, still a pretty good game, especially when you get into the grove of it and learn how to consistently win.

134041177.review:
One of my favorite roguelikes ever.

The good:
Banging chiptune OST.
Wonderful golden era Cartoon Network aesthetic. Witty dialog.
Excellent sound effects that really add zip to your dice battles.
Multiple characters with multiple challenges ensure so much variety in gameplay and adaptation required to tackle different runs.
I ran out of steam around the 50 hour mark, but there's plenty of game to return to should I want to later.
It'll run on a potato.

The meh:
Some reviews here complain about the randomness. It never bothered me. However, what *did* bother me was that some challenges with certain characters were WAY harder than others.  I must have spent 5 hours unsuccessfully trying to beat Thief on the Elimination Round before I just gave up to try my hand at other challenges and characters. This is a hard game to 100%.

The verdict:
This is a near-perfect roguelike that I would recommend to almost anyone (except compulsive achievement hunters). And I'm sure I'll come back to tackle a couple more remaining challenges later.

I will warn you, you do have to save scum for those witch levels haha. Everything about this game works and fits together well, and it's random rng usually feels fair until your fighting that damn Loud Bird.

132598071.review:
The most fun you can have with dice in 30 minutes or less.

I absolutely love Dicey Dungeons. Every character is well defined and fully realized. The music is catchy and intense. The voice acting, sound, and animation bring the creative characters to life.

This game is perfectly crafted to give just enough depth and just enough variety to keep coming me back for more in short and satisfying episodes. I love the balancing act between choosing a strong attack vs limiting the inherent randomness of rolling dice when upgrading and choosing skills.

The pacing of Dicey Dungeons is immaculate. It starts simple and keeps adding more complexity at steady rate. Each character offers a unique puzzle to solve inherent to them. Once I felt like I figured out a character, the next episode adds a fresh new twist on the strategy I just mastered.

The greatest strength of the game is how quick and easy it is the complete a run. It manages to be fun if I need something to play for 20 to 30 minutes, or I just finished a run and want to play "just one more".

132578792.review:
The premise of assigning dice in battles as you work your way through an increasingly difficult dungeon was what initially drew me to this game, as I tend to like similar game mechanics and it provides a digital alternative to tabletop games. There is a lot to like in this game, from the variety of characters, abilities, and enemies to the decision making required in battles and equipment selection.

Unfortunately from my experience, strategy and decision making can only get you so far in this game. While RNG is to be expected in a game involving dice, this particular implementation seemed to be especially punishing, in particular with stronger enemies and bosses. You can have a really great set of equipment, cruise your way through most of the dungeon, only for things to take a sharp turn near the end through no fault of your own. You can only do so much when 75% of your dice are burned because the enemy rolled exactly what they needed several turns in a row, or a bunch of your equipment is weakened via shock every turn, or all your dice are 1's because they all got frozen. These issues are exasperated when you throw in some of the hindrances via later episode rules. Because of all this, I cannot recommend this game.

132221269.review:
I must admit that I have not delved much into the deckbuilding genre with touches of roguelike, and without a doubt the one that has stayed with me the most has been Slay the Spire, who many will know. However, I find it to be a rather curious style of game that is perfect for both short and long gaming sessions, which is why this title managed to capture my attention, especially for its charming visual section which I found very attractive from the beginning.

Dicey Dungeons is a creative and interesting proposal in the deckbuilding roguelike genre, putting as protagonists the very mechanics of the game and depicting the characters as dice: the RNG itself, right. It’s presented as a peculiar adventure where we must explore the dungeons of the Lady Fortune, challenging her in a series of games and confrontations to find an incredible prize at the end. Having several episodes and different characters to explore, I found it quite promising.

The story, as I mentioned, is given through episodes that we can unlock as we progress, defeating bosses and completing mazes. All of this unfolds in a "TV quiz show" fashion, with voiceovers by the antagonist and other characters such as the jester, prize wheels and so on, which I found quite entertaining and unique. Each character has their own reason for venturing into the dungeon, but the plot is still pretty much the same for everyone: get to the end and claim the reward. However, Lady Fortune will challenge and hinder us at every step we take, and said loot will seem farther and farther away; does it even exist? I can't answer that question, nor do I have much more to share regarding this section, since I haven't finished the game at the moment (after all I'm pretty bad at roguelikes), but I want to make it clear that I find it very curious and enjoyable.

I found the visual section charming and very unique, featuring a very particular artstyle that reminds me of coloring books and some watercolor or crayon, cartoonish so to speak. The "protagonists" are designed in a very simple way, as they are dice that differ from each other by some visual characteristics, such as: the thief who wears an eye patch and dual daggers, or the robot who well, is a robot with screws and an antenna on his head. The enemies and bosses are very varied and colorful, and change depending on the area we find ourselves in, with different levels and their own specific attacks. The environments and menus go pretty much hand in hand with the rest of the art, and it's all very pleasing to the eye, in my opinion.

The soundtrack is phenomenal! I loved the various tunes I heard, and the mixes between techno, chiptune and electronic. This is definitely my favorite aspect of the game so far. It's not every day that a game of this style, turn-based or similar, becomes so exciting to me thanks to its catchy and upbeat music that keeps me much more hooked than I expected; I appreciate the dedication to this section by the developers, as it really captivated me.

On the gameplay side, it's a fairly simple roguelike to learn, but at the same time a bit difficult and that relies, in my opinion, a bit too much on the RNG aspect. Maybe it's because I'm not very good at these games, but I feel that luck is a very prominent factor in this particular title; although, the game has a "relaxed" mode, which I imagine makes the experience more enjoyable, but I'm playing it on normal difficulty so to speak, so yeah! Leaving aside my opinions, I will comment that the game is handled in two parts: exploration, with inventory and resource management, and combat. Exploration is presented to us on a sort of board with linked squares. In some squares you will find enemies (with which you can initiate combat by moving towards them), healing apples, stores or upgrading anvils. 

Inventory management is based on choosing which "weapons" we will use in combat, since we will have a limit at our disposal, and there will be boxes in which we can place our dice to release their effects in the middle of the battle. Some of these tools require specific dice, such as one that can do up to 3 damage and can be reused, but the maximum value of the dice must be 3. Others have altered states, such as freezing the opponent's dice, reducing their level to 1, or burning them so that the opponent suffers collateral damage when using them.

As we defeat enemies we will level up, increasing the amount of dice we can use in combat, which will help us to better use the characters' abilities. Each character has their own style of play, some being better benefited by high value rolls such as 4 or 6, and some applying the opposite and managing better with amounts between 1 and 3. The Thief, for example, has reusable tools that allow him to double or split dice to make better use of his attacks, which usually do little damage but can be devastating if you manage to form a chain or sequence with them. There is enough versatility with these attacks and tools, being able to buy or obtain different versions in the stores, improving those already obtained, or by defeating enemies, thus generating some customization for each game; this gameplay loop so iconic of a roguelike is what the game bets on the most in my opinion, and I found it a pretty well thought out system, which I really liked its execution, even though the game itself is a bit hard for me in general.

In conclusion, Dicey Dungeons is a very elaborate and peculiar title, in my opinion, a very entertaining and striking proposal of the deckbuilder and roguelike genre. The very charismatic art and the amazing soundtrack are the icing on the cake, and while I mentioned that I haven't finished the game, I wanted to write a review to recommend it, as I think fans of this type of games should give it a try!

Really fun game although it may get boring fast. Each Dice has unique gameplay and gear for each chapter and most of them are really fun. (SPOILERS AHEAD FOR PLAYABLE CHARACTERS)
* The Warrior. Your standar fighter. Big sword, big damage and big shield if you get the right gear. A really fun way to get into the game.
* The Thief. The traditional rogue. Deal lots of low damage attacks, you also steal enemy equipment which creates some funny interactions.
* The robot. This is where i really start liking the game, the robot starts bringing unique gameplay like choosing which number you want to roll, really fun.
* The inventor. You remember how i said the robot is the most fun? Here i present you the most frustrating dice. The inventor! the only dice that punishes you for fighting enemies. Forget about having fun, you are now forced to micromanage every single fight because you lose one equipment at the end of every encounter. You will hate her too, specially on later chapters.
* The Witch. Look, i play a lot of D&D and rollgames so i knew the wizard or any kind of caster would be one of the classes here. The witch has potential to be fun but it's the hardest of them all, not as unfun as the inventor but she will be your last dice to complete.
* The Jester. Previously your foe in the dungeons, the jester rebels against Lady Luck and gets turned into dice. The jester is a nice breath of fresh air from the two previous dice. Hes fun, random and has the best one-turn kill potential of all dice. Really nice dude.

In conclusion. Game is fun, a bit frustrating if you go for completionist but i have played worse. I wouldn't recommend getting it at full price tho, wait for a sale or get it on Game Pass.

130498815.review:
I really want to like this game, I really do. The art is interesting, the music is great and the presentation is fantastic. 
I also really like roguelites (you can see it from my profile), and the main gimmick with this game (ie, every action depends on a dice roll) interests me a lot.

The reason I cannot recommend this game is because the player has not enough agency to change the outcome of a run in this game. The choices you can make in terms of your "deck" in a run are pretty limited, there is no meta progression, there are no artifacts that change the shape of a run. You are basically given a set of equipment, you can find new ones or upgrade the existing ones during a run, and that's it. In each encounter you know perfectly well what you need, but you cannot alter your destiny in any way, shape or form. Sometimes you are lucky, sometimes you are unlucky, and have to restart from the beginning, wasting a good 30 minutes in the worst scenario. This can happen in other roguelites, don't get me wrong, but at least you have learned something, you can try to understand what choices were suboptimal and ultimately led to a failure, and consequently adjust in later playthroughs. Here you can just praise or hate the RNG-god, and be left with a sour aftertaste on both cases.

Each character is unique, and I appreciate the innovations this game was trying for. However I really think it needs some additional system to keep the RNG in check and allow the player some ways to mitigate the consequences of a few bad rolls.

PS: "50% chanche for an equipment to do nothing this turn" is not a particularly interesting effect, to put it mildly...

130011486.review:
[i]Dicey Dungeons[/i] is very chill and low-effort, which is exactly what I need sometimes. It's a great game to play while listening to a podcast or watching a YouTube video. At the same time, it's surprisingly addictive. The different characters and "episodes" provide a lot of variety in how the game plays, making every run feel different and fresh. I haven't finished the main story yet, but I'm interested to see where it goes, and the interactions between the characters are cute and cleverly written. I also love the soundtrack.

The game is pretty heavily RNG-based, and good or bad outcomes can quickly snowball to the point of your character being either irredeemably doomed or insanely overpowered. But... it's a game about dice, so it should be expected that RNG will play a big role.

Edited to add: [i]Dicey Dungeons[/i] does get pretty repetitive once you've completed all six episodes with a few contestants. I wish I could advance the story without having to complete all thirty-six episodes. I still think the game is worth the price, especially if you get it on sale, but I would have liked some of the repetitive episodes to be left as bonus content rather than a requirement for completion of the main story.

129362669.review:
This game is fun. If you're a person who gets annoyed by unfair punishment and inability to optimize your play on sightread, it is also really annoying.

Visuals/aesthetic are great. This uses a simple almost minimalist art style and still manages to be very cute, clean and nice to look at. It's a lovable atmosphere even if overly innocent/cartoony. Music also matches the flavor of the game perfectly.

In regards to unfair punishment... the game gives the appreciated ability to change your equipment/build between fights. Obviously you're supposed to move it around based on not just your overall build, but who your opponent is. The problem is you will have no idea what an enemy is like until you start the fight, where it immediately tells you "enemy is weak against x" and you can see what their attacks are. Building around your opponent would add enjoyable depth to the game. But the only way to do it is by guessing, looking up the enemies, or already having encountered them before and remembering. Why? Give the information so I can use the game's systems to their fullest, without punishing me simply for not having information you should be supplying in the first place. The only way to play optimally is be punished repeatedly for something that isn't your fault until you memorize the enemies, or look them up constantly. 

You are also regularly forced to make decisions without being able to view your current deck, or check if the current battle will level you up or not. While playing one character, you even have to remember every single spell beacuse you can't see them before choosing. Mid-turn this is a unnecessary disaster. The worst one is being unable to see your current deck when making choices that rely on the rest of your deck.. this is comically stupid, no excuses. You can't even view your deck while you're buying stuff at a store. You have to exit and check a separate screen while making a plan, back and forth. But in some situations you can't check your deck in any way until making the choice.

But again, the game is pretty fun. It's just really painful to be punished for something that isn't my fault, and deal with endless situations where the game refuses to give proper information for no good reason other than lack of foresight, I guess. They give tools for overcoming adversity, while refusing to tell us what adversity we need to overcome until it's too late. Much about the game is a good time, but it's so much worse than it could have been for very obvious reasons.

129169465.review:
tl;dr: Game doesn´t derserve the tag "Roguelike-Deckbuilder". There isn´t much deckbuilding and the little deckbuilding left is broken by the aviable cards/items and a limited size of your "deck", which feels more like items you equip to a character. Do not buy the game if you desire a classic Deckbuilder. 

In Detail:
The game got very boring in the first and only 45min I was willing to play. For a "Roguelike-Deckbuilder" the possibilites are very limited: At the beginning I already noticed, that I will need to have the healing crystal, because otherwise I would run out of Healthpoints against the otherwise massivly annoying enemies. They have too many special attacks that will deduct your HP in a form or another (burning or poison). Therefore I kept that card (healingcrystal) always equiped and upgraded it, which let me won the first run in a very uninteresting and boring way. The need for healing crystal took away a slot away, which resulted in less possible combinations. 

Together with the fact, that there aren´t many slots for cards either I must say, that this game doesn´t deserve the title "Roguelike-Deckbuilder". The cards you equip feel more like the standard items you equip  to a RPG character just spiced up by the factor, which have a RNG based condition (diceroll) to be useable. Imagine a RPG where you can´t use your cool sword becasue RNG said: Nope. A very boring concept and I expected the game to bring therefore more slots for items/cards, but they didn´t came. Just more dices (yikes!). There are also too many card in this game with such special conditions. To be fair: You can upgrade most of them to make them use any dice, as far as I saw. However, the general flaw is the concept of items/cards, that are only usable when RNG-God is willling to help. Also: why aren´t there any artifacts that would spice up things a bit more? Artifacts that you can rely on?

Because of that I will refund the game and tell you, that it isn´t even worth it in a sale like the current one (Winter Sale 2022; reduced to ~3€). There are just too many other good real Roguelike-Deckbuilders and this game is only worth it, if you feel bored by the other deckbuilders that stick to the (in my oppinion: better) established concepts.

129149942.review:
The Thief is in it to win, which is ironic because the game show is rigged.  Well, it's the taking part that counts.  So what else can you do in Dicey Dungeons?  
 - retry a previous round or select a new character
 - pass up on skills, coins and experience or fight for them

Don't let the cutesy art fool you! This one is a real nail-biter through and through.

The "press your luck" element of the dice based equipment can really test your ability to assess calculated risks. There's already been a few situations where I had to hit that perfect 6, or I was DEAD next turn.

Thankfully, the game adds in a number of ways to split, lift, and squish dice to fit your needs.

My first couple runs had me scratching my head at some seemingly useless equipment. But, lo and behold, there were some busted combos to later be found! Each character has very different playstyles, so you're sure to find new puzzles and approaches with each run.

Slay the Spire is probably still the gold standard, but I'd give Dicey Dungeons a strong silver.

P.S. It helps a lot to plan out your turn and what numbers you want before you start spending dice. One or two false moves can mean big missed opportunities.

128466481.review:
There is a distinct lack of player agency in Dicey Dungeons which leads to an unsatisfying experience. In a proper roguelike, the player can take satisfaction in their choices having meaning, even when resulting in a loss, as there's usually so much to learn and apply to the next run. This game not only lacks these properties, but in many playthroughs, it feels as if there were no meaningful decisions to be made at all. Often, going up against RNG feels like slamming your head against a brick wall--no amount of skill can circumvent running bad in this game. In fact, skill is often a non-factor in the tougher challenges. The game lacks the depth and complexity to make your decisions have weight.

As one familiarizes themselves with the shallow enemy roster it becomes obviously apparent which strategies might work, but the game rarely gives you the tools to realize them. Your run is generally left up to which random assortment of equipment you happen to get; of which you have few chances to augment. For example, you might run into many enemies weak to fire in your run, but sometimes you just don't get a piece of fire equipment. Or maybe you get a shield synergy payoff, but don't get any shield-generating equipment. Not that you should always get the perfect builds, but it just feels so all or nothing in this game.

Most of my experience is with the warrior, but I have played a decent amount of the other classes. None of which sway my negative opinion.

The aesthetic is what attracted to me to this game and it meets all expectations. I wanted a roguelike with simpler mechanics and I believe this game delivers there as well. So I can see why many people enjoy this game. It just isn't for me.

127819401.review:
Please buy this game, you get 2.5 whole games for the price of one. I highly recommend it to any roguelite or card game fan, and even though I've played many roguelites, this has easily wormed its way into my top 5.

A quick disclaimer though, the roguelite aspect of it in terms of replayability only kicks in for the 6th round for each character. I've seen reviews complaining about the lack of a roguelite aspect in this regard, but many of those reviews only have a few hours in the game. The 6th round is where it ties everything together and offers true replayability. 

The base game is already a fantastic game with beautiful art, banger music, funny dialogue, and importantly great gameplay. 

You have 6 characters to choose from, each of which having 6 different scenarios to play for said character (although some are similar like "Elimination Round", which adds 10% hp to each enemy and is everyone's 5th way to play). Each character naturally has several build paths to choose from, allowing for variety in the way you play each character.

There is a Parallel Universe scenario which completely flips how mechanics work, and makes most of the player's cards completely new, as if it was a DLC on its own. This allows for even more build paths for each character, and the final round combines all the cards and most of the new mechanics while adding special modifiers each floor you go to.

The game also comes with 2 Bonus Modes for free, which are essentially DLC. The first one is a Halloween mode which lets you play with 3 characters in a new way, as well as adding 3 enemies. The second one is a sort of "Farewell" or "Labour of Love" update, added 2.5 years into the game for free.

This second DLC, named Reunion? It's like Dicey Dungeons 2.0. Everything is brand new, all the enemies have new cards that still fit their theme, almost every card is something new, they've added new mechanics, and swapped up how the players are. This has no business being free for such a huge content update, reminding me of Enter The Gungeon which similarly gave huge updates for free. The developer also gave their development thoughts here, if you want to read them: 

http://distractionware.com/blog/category/dicey-dungeons/

All in all, it is a fantastic game. It has its flaws, but they are very minor (the trading station has been useless almost every single time I've seen it, and some status effects are super rare and only caused by 1 enemy, although this later one seems to be rectified with the DLC, the system can be broken in your favour with savescumming and hitting the enemies with die before they/the cards get locked out by debuffs).

also the witch is trash the elimination round brings severe pain don't do it save yourself

127613904.review:
I have tried to purchase and enjoy this game three separate times. Terry Cavanagh is one of my favorite game designers of all time, and Super Hexagon/VVVVVV are two of my favorite games. I kept feeling like I was 'missing something', because everyone else enjoys this game so much.

It seems to me, however, that this game is not a rogue-like in any proper sense. Instead of having a generalized 'run', you pick a character, then pick an 'episode', which structures the entire playstyle of your run by restricting the character you like and have picked, making their abilities different every time thus making it impossible for you to simply jump into a run and enjoy yourself. You always have to pick a different class, a different arbitrary new ability, and there's little to no replayability once you've cleared an 'episode'. I certainly can't see any reason to play this game at all if you're looking for a 'rogue-like' anything... it makes me angry because it's advertised with procedural generation and randomized content, but all the content is restricted to 'boards' that are pre-arranged and simply shuffle the data points within. This would be like if in Dead Cells you could only pick your build before starting your run, and it was limited to one weapon, and that weapon lost the ability you enjoyed losing it for and got some new random and stupid ability every run after. I seriously don't feel this counts as a 'rogue-like' at all and I feel advertising it as once is deceptive at best and immoral at worst.

All this game would have to do is add a general randomized mode without the episodic restrictions, and I would love it. But it doesn't have that after multiple updates, and it still has stuff like unskippable tutorials and forcing you to play new characters to unlock content and the aforementioned 'episodes' being the most terrible content delivery method I've witnessed in a game in a long time... 

I don't recommend you buy this game. That's all.

126995564.review:
Fantastic, light-hearted, but compelling Roguelite.

A classic roguelite, work your way through a small dungeon, improving equipment, and trying to beat the boss. Lighthearted in tone, but fun, strategic gameplay. 

Instead of yet another Slay the Spire clone, this has it's own unique mechanics. Roll some dice, use them on your eqipment, some equipment only works with specific rolls or need odd or even rolls. Other equipment lets you modify what you do roll for more control, there's a lot going on strategically.

6 characters, all with unique mechanics that make each feel distinct and interesting. Runs feel completely different depending on who you use. There are multiple 'episodes' which tweak the rules in interesting ways and force you to rethink your strategies.

Don't be put off by the dice. The rolls may be random, but wins or losses come down to how you build your character and the decisions you make. 

Obvious comparisons are games like Card Hunter or Guild of Dungeoneering, but this is much better, more strategic and enjoyable than either of those.

Not sure it's one you'd come back to over and over once you have the achievements but a complete blast while it lasts.

126078946.review:
A roguelite with cute visuals and story, Dicey Dungeons uses relatively simple mechanics to create surprisingly varied game play.

As a contestant on a game show cursed to keep running a gauntlet, the story is integrated quite well with the concept of rogues. Lady Luck is an entertaining villain and each character you unlock comes with a unique personality and mechanics.

Completing trials/runs unlocks more contestants to play as and new trials. Rather than simply give enemies more hit points, trials completely change certain mechanics in use giving the game almost a puzzle-like quality rather than straight strategy.

The basic, consistent mechanic across all characters is to equip certain items that can damage, heal, shield, or apply status effects. Then, each round during combat, you roll dice and use them to activate your gear where only certain rolls can be used or certain rolls will add more effects. Since monsters will have their own gear and effects, if you have enough gear (it is a rogue, so sometimes you do and sometimes...), then you can strategize by swapping to more favourable gear to increase your odds of success.

While some runs felt like I could do everything right and fail based on character + gear + rolls vs. specific enemies, more often than not I felt like with cunning and prep I could succeed. And, since each run was pretty short, even getting pantsed by the boss was only mildly frustrating and I found myself wanting to go in again.
Also, with free bonus episodes being released 3years on, the devs clearly care about their game and it shows.

125886816.review: This is a really good game. It is of the roguelike cloth, but some of the more annoying aspects of the genre that are present in this game can be excused by the fact that it was originally released before the absolute explosion of roguelikes in the indiesphere occurred in the last few years. Looking past those flaws-that-weren't-flaws-before-they-got-overdone, what's left is: a deep and engaging turn-based combat system that has a bit of rng, but a lot of ways to control for that risk; a marvelous soundtrack by the one and only Chipzel; so many different spins and takes on the core gameplay with several different characters and scenarios; and some funny and clever dialogue/plot. There are 36 unique scenarios, not counting dlc, yet I completed all of it and still wanted more.
