124940447.review:
I know what you're thinking. "How original. A dice themed dungeon crawler? Woooo. Yeah, pass." That's exactly what I thought when I saw this. And that was a sin so grave, that when I got hit by a passing truck and died, I went to hell for it. It's actually not so bad - good company - but I still feel like you shouldn't make the same mistake as I did. 

Because this game isn't just good. As in, yeah, it's fun to play, the characters are cute and interesting, the soundtrack is more fire than hell itself (trust me on this one)... but what's really going on here is that the [b]game design[/b] is black magic levels of intricate and tight. It's elegant, it's very deep, and it's so insanely varied that you can spend an eternity playing this and still have fun. In fact, that's what I am doing - at the time of writing I have 117 hours, and I only died like last week!

At its core, Dicey Dungeons is a deckbuilder where action points are replaced by dice. You collect items (think cards), which you can put into your "battle deck" to use in combat, usually by feeding them one of your dice. Every character has their own set of items - some overlap, but not many - and there's a LOT of them. I have 100% achievement completion and beat all extra content, and when I watch friends play this game I *still* sometimes see cards that I've never seen before - mind, that's not due to missing unlocks, there's no such thing in this game.

Still, that wouldn't matter much if the core gameplay was bad. It's not. Yes, you have to rely on dice rolls, but there are ways to minimise your reliance on the RNG. And that's what this game really is about - constructing a deck that will keep you going in most circumstances, and then cleverly maximising the value of your dice. For example, take the Thief. His default loadout contains a Dagger; it's infinitely reusable, but it only accepts dice with 3 or lower. It's fine if you roll low, but what if you start rolling high? Well, in that case you either need some items that will split your dice into lower values, or something that will actually accept the high rolls. Which will it be? This is one of the most basic decisions you'll be making in this game. 

There are multiple characters to choose from, too, each with their own special skill, a "limit break" ability (charged up by taking damage), and a general "theme" of items. Warrior is your typical high roller, roll high, bam, raw damage. The aforementioned Thief is the opposite; he wants to roll low (at least initially) and kill with a thousand tiny attacks. But then things get weird. There's the Robot, who doesn't roll all the dice but instead has a... CPU counter which increases with each roll? And it only gets weirder from there. To top it all off, things get heavily remixed in later episodes, and additional content switches things up even further. Like I said, black magic of game design.

So the game's good. Hellishly good, in fact. I've talked to Natalia, a witch from the 13th century, and she says this stuff would've totally gotten Terry Cavanagh burned at the stake back in her day. But there are a lot of good, yet overlooked games; why missing this one was enough to condemn me to eternal damnation?

Because on top of all that, the game manages to have a cast of lovable, diverse, unique, and just plain great characters - both your guys as well as the enemies. The game's dialogue is then used to tell a story - and that story is great as well! And it's all wraped in this pleasant, detailed graphical style, mixed with a strange musical concoction by Chipzel. She's always been a chiptune/electro artist, but now she threw some... SWING in? So you get a blend of chiptune, some decently hard bass and samples of saxophone, trumpet and even light vocals. And believe me when I say that the compositions themselves are TIGHT. There's one particular piece that just completely flies off the handle when it comes to (my understanding of) music theory; it's absolutely glorious.

Okay, look, Satan just came and told me that this review is proof enough of my repentance, so they're sending me back. I almost told him "no thanks", but then I remembered that this game exists in the mortal realm too, so I guess I'll keep on playing games and writing reviews for a few more decades, hopefully. And you should probably check out this game. It's pretty neat, I'd say.

124333296.review:
Edit Review as of 28 Oct 2022: I've obtained all achievements!!! :D

[Pay$-to-Play]  While I would love to obtain all achievements before writing a review,  this is my 100th Review :O and I wanted to reserve it for a game that holds a special place in my heart ^_^ and I think Dicey Dungeons fits the criteria!

This game is very cute, I love its art, andd while it seems simple/easy to play there are lots of planning and strategy and RNG involved; of hoping to get good rolls, weapons, enemies etc. We can play 5 job characters (+1) and each of them have different combat styles and specials. 

I must admit, I was really bad at the game initially and just couldnt even clear the 'easiest stage' - Warrior Level 1 no matter how many times I did, so I asked for a refund :P ... But then, this game was always at the back of my mind due to its charming nature and when there was sales a second time, I bought it again xD

Thereafter, I read up on strategies and got used to the mechanism. When our special power is charged, we should use them at the appropriate time and not as and when it is available (as it requires hp deduction to charge) . Even eating apples is a strategy; we should not be eating apples blindly and only eat when needed / health is almost half or less.

Once I understood these concepts, I was able to clear stages after stages. However; a lot of luck and strategy is still needed to clear later stages.

As of writing, I did clear the 36 normal episodes and defeated Lady Luck. Just when I thought the normal stages is already tough (I struggled with Thief & Witch mostly) ; there's a Hard Mode version ._.
(Imma do my best and hopefully I can get 100% :))

Tags: [Fun] [Cute] [Dice] [Strategy] [RNG-based]

An excellent roguelike game that's easy to get into. 
The music and designs are very nice, and the gameplay is fun : each turn basically feels like you have a simple puzzle to solve. There's simple basic rules and an amount of hidden rules you can discover by doing experiments, which give the gameplay a bit more depth. 
My main regret is that runs are always tailored and balanced for a specific character, and are rather short, I wish there would be more freedom in what we can encounter or who you can play as (a mode with longer runs would be nice, or one you can play as any monster as an actul character like they did with the bear).

122447559.review:
[h1] A simpler roguelike [/h1]

Dicey Dungeons is a fairly simple yet fun little roguelike. Whilst it lacks the depth of some other roguelikes both in gameplay mechanics ([url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/646570/Slay_the_Spire/]Slay the Spire[/url], for example) and narrative ([url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1145360/Hades/]Hades[/url], for example), it somewhat makes up for this with it's simplicity and ease-of-access for those new to the genre. 

Main pros:

- Gameplay is simple and will be easily understood even for those brand new to the genre. There's an optional easy mode and the ability to straight up skip progression making it even more accessible to newbies / young players. 
- Decent amount of content available with free DLC being added

Main cons:

- Progression system lacks flexibility (why can't I keep playing one character at the start, mastering them before moving onto somebody else?)
- Characters and dialogue are generally uninteresting
- Music is hit and miss. Some music is great whilst some is a bit grating
- Artstyle is alright, but the childlike aesthetic isn't my thing

For those new to the roguelike genre, this game may be ideal for you. It's simple yet complex enough to be interesting. Those looking for a great deal of depth and replayability may want to give this one a pass.

Side note, the creator of this game made [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Misanu/recommended/70300/]VVVVVV[/url], which is a great little platforming game I highly recommend checking out if you want to burn a few hours.

6/10

122294591.review:
This is a very solid game, bopping music, cute and colorful artstyle, fun gameplay for the most of it.

I'll admit, I expected to be blown away by it more since it is a Terry Cavanagh game, VVVVVV and Super Hexagon were these out of the water surprises that both had the very foundation of the gameplay be so distinctly different from anything else out there and had the most surreal looks and themes to dress up the gameplay in.

Dicey Dungeons is if you get down to it, an indie roguelike dungeon crawler with a turn based combat system, even if it does not directly feature deck building for the most of it(aside the Jester, who goes all in and makes it into a deck builder too) it is very hard to shake the comparisons to Slay the Spire (or the myriad of other card battlers) on a gameplay level.
Your equipment(or Jester's deck) is essentially like the cards of StS, that the dice act like mana/energy that can be used to activate the cards if the conditions are met and you balance your dice pool to go into attacking, blocking, healing or casting buffs/debuffs.
With the really low power attack that gives max HP on a kill and that Jester card that skips enemy turn completely like Spire's Vault card ending up being a little too familiar.

There's a few extra flavors of card shenanigans too, the Robot's basically Blackjack, and the Witch is like all of the card games where you arrange your cards on the table in a formation and then do the battling.
It is really hard to shake the feeling of Dicey Dungeons being of a card battler in disguise, but the game doesn't outright embrace being one, so it doesn't really redefine the genre in a groundbreaking way.

The game had some really fresh ideas though, but with the scattershot approach, not many were elaborated on much.
The Robot in the Reunion update had the Blackjack mechanic being retrofitted to use coins instead of dice complete with a brand new set of equipment balanced around that. That's the crazy new ideas I expected the game to be full of.
But even if you play a trick character like the Inventor, Witch or Robot, it is still hard to escape it turning into just being the basic Warrior feel of, have high power attacking gear and some form of rolls manipulation/dice duplication, and just destroy.
The Witch's update levels turning into preset puzzle levels particularly stings, yes the levels are very fun, but no, it still leaves the whole set of Witch mechanics with plenty of untapped potential unexplored.

I wouldn't say this game is even that hard for a roguelike, and the most deaths you'll likely going to have will end up being either Elimination Round or Hard Mode Bonus Round.
With the enemy equipment being upgraded and them having more HP, it is way too RNG based and it will boil down a lot to "Well, I made the perfect play for this turn, I just have to hope enemy doesn't roll cartoonishly high and take out 60% of my HP in one turn" in those modes.

It's not quite the Extreme difficulty campaigns in 100% Orange Juice where the enemies have literal rigged dice rolls, but those levels get frustrating where you lose to pure RNG, and that's not even the item drop RNG giving you a weak build.

TL:DR Yes, it is a good indie roguelike card battler(yes, I'll stick to calling it a card battler), it has just enough interesting twists to not be an outright rehash of the done to death genre, but it features too much of a scattershot approach to not go anywhere with any of the more original mechanics, so it doesn't redefine, subvert or create anew any genre.
It also lacks a fair bit of that mindblowing "whoa what is this, I've never seen stuff like this" past Terry Cavanagh games had (pursuing a done to death genre certainly did not help).

121674998.review:
[b]Dicey Dungeons[/b] is a deckbuilding dungeon crawler created by Terry Cavanagh.
It (usually) strikes a fair balance between skill and luck. [b]More on that (usually) later.[/b]

[h1]Layout[/h1]
The game is divided into episodes. Each character has 6 episodes in the base game, 1 episode in the free Reunion DLC, and three of the characters has 1 episode in the free Halloween Special, making for a grand total of 45 episodes. Thanks to the random elements, the episodes have good replayability however, and I'll definitely see myself replaying some of my favourites in the future.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[h3]Overworld[/h3]
For each episode you're tasked with making it through a dungeon and defeating a boss at the end. A dungeon normally consists of 5 normal floors and 1 boss floor. The goal on each floor is to reach the hatch leading down to the next floor. In your way are enemies which you need to defeat in battle in order to get past.

You get experience from defeating enemies, and after getting enough you go up a level.
Because of this, even if some enemies are not blocking you from reaching the hatch, you might go and fight them anyway. You need to defeat every single enemy in order to be max level at the boss. This is not a necessity, but (usually) a good idea. [b]More on that (usually) later.[/b]

You also gain coins from battles which you can use to buy new equipment from shops you find throughout the dungeon. You also encounter chests which contain random new equipment, and anvils which you can use to upgrade a piece of equipment to a more powerful version, amongst some other surprises.

[h3]Battles[/h3]
Enemies are fought one on one.
Your turn begins with rolling the number of dice your character has. You then put those dice on your equipment cards to play them. Some equipment need even or odd numbers to be played, some can only use a maximum of 4, a minimum of 3, etc.

After you've done everything you want, you give the turn over to the enemy, which then proceeds with the same procedure using their equipment and dice. This goes on until either you or the enemy is dead.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Each of the characters enter the game show Dicey Dungeons hosted by Lady Luck, the personification of luck and fate, in order to win their heart's desire. If they survive a trip through the dungeons they get to spin a wheel and get a chance at winning their prize!

Things start to become more and more suspicious as you keep playing though. How can the wheel keep landing on the one slice that's a dud? What's with the weird comments from Lady Luck that you'll make a fine minion? I think you see where this is going.

I particularily like how all the enemies you fight are actually previous contestants that gave up on winning and resigned to their fate, and most of them have a bio in the bestiary where you can read what their reason for entering the dungeon was.

And yes, I like the underdog stories. Challenging Lady Luck to a game of dice? There's just no way you can win, right?

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]
This game's soundtrack is composed by Chipzel, who has made some bangin' remixes of the Crypt of the Necrodancer soundtrack before this.

The soundtrack is for the most part a fusion of jazz and chiptune, and really good.
Some battle music samples: [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oGL5m0qWzWA]Fighting Chance[/url], [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=C0EwPLS1Gec]Tempting Fate[/url], and a personal favourite, [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eKUAqS7mFrI]Step Right Up[/url].
The Reunion DLC's battle themes are all bangers as well.

[h1]Luck[/h1]
With the story setting and deck buildery and random generation dungeonry, a question that always pops up is "how much luck is too much luck?"

[url=https://twitter.com/terrycavanagh/status/1183808542484127749]This game is fair[/url]: the rolls for you and the enemy are completely random with the exception of the final boss (I think you can guess who and why).

But people are not good with probabilities in general. Most also tend to forget the times luck was in their favour. Bad luck is more easily remembered since they can cost you your run on floor 4 or 5, which is far enough into a run to make you say "Dungeon Crawler? More like Dungeon Crawling in My Skin."

The game allows you to mitigate the luck element for yourself through some dice manipulation equipment however. There's for example Lockpick, which splits a die into two dice, and Spatula, which flips the die upside down, turning a 1 into a 6 for example. Careful use of these equipments can (usually) turn a bad situation into a good one. [b]More on that (usually) later.[/b]

Still, in the words of a certain starfleet captain:
"It is possible to commit no mistakes and still lose."

You'll have to ask yourself if you can deal with the fact that you'll lose some runs to bad luck.

[h1](usually)[/h1]
One of the characters' episodes (Witch's Elimination Round), is brutal and more luck-dependent than most episodes. In the Elimination Rounds, enemies have inflated health and UPGRADED equipment. The Witch has a certain gimmick that needs some setup in order to pay off, but enemies tend to oblitirate you before you can finish if they get have luck on their side. She can also be crippled early on by bad dice rolls. Runs can and will end on floor 1 sometimes.

I think this episode needs more powerful equipment, or more chests early on in order to smooth out the giant spike in difficulty. It took me 20 runs to win, but I've seen some poor bastards take upwards 150 runs before a victory. Of course, they might not have played optimally, but still.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
A great game, if you can deal with Lady Luck in several senses.

My playtime of 66 hours involves beating all 45 episodes and getting all the achievements (which involved replaying some episodes). The average dungeon crawl took around 35 minutes.

I didn't even talk about the art or enemy design, but these are also very good.
Baby Squid is a Beautiful Cinnamon Roll Too Good For This World, Too Pure™

Oh right, I've opened up to these types of games thanks to Dicey Dungeons.
I thought I didn't like deck builders, but I was happy to be proven wrong.

If you're in the same boat, I hope you give this one a try.
It might just change your mind!

121089973.review:
Cute, sufficiently interesting, uncomplicated. All this adds together to make a great game for feeling like you're having fun, but they don't add up to make a great game for feeling like winning is Truly Accomplishing Something.

Cute: everything is kind of banal and pleasant, such that you do not get stressed out by tough battles. I find some of the aesthetic to be a bit eye-rolling / my soul is generally dead to some of the cuteness attempts. But it's never particularly objectionable to me, and sometimes I actually am charmed by the cuteness, so on balance, this is a cute and not annoying game.

Sufficiently interesting: Good variety in the characters (which give you subsets of the main item deck) and in the makeup of the items, decent variety in the enemies, rougelite format and wide variety of starting modifications to the character/deck/rules means that there will always be something for your brain to engage with...

Uncomplicated: ...But not *too* much variety. I scrolled through the reviews to find a few critical ones before starting this review, and the most fair criticism I saw was that the potential for synergy is low. This is absolutely true compared to more complicated deckbuilding games like Slay the Spire or Monster Train. When you want to hyperfocus on an epic deckbuilding game, don't start this one. When you want to chill out, see how a run goes, this is a great game. You will not reach the peaks of thrill granted by combo-whombo-stacks-on-stacks with this game, but it's pretty easy to do pretty good. If you are sometimes or always in the mood for this, for sure buy this game. If you want to engage with a super intellectually stimulating deckbuilding game, maybe try another one.

Another pleasant benefit of the more-chill, less-hyperfocussy [i](...lol get dat hyperfocussy.......)[/i] nature of the game is that it's way more easy and tempting to pick the game up after a long time of not playing it. While I absolutely love other classic and more intellectual deckbuilding games, I find that I tend to, in certain seasons of life, get totally deep into them, play them often and for long sessions, then eventually lose interest and put them down. (My experience with them is the kind of thing gamers describe as "addicting".) Later on, if I remember one of those games fondly, I might try to fire it up again, but realize that I'm not in practice for them anymore and getting into the grove again is hard. (Any deeply skill-based games and hobbies are usually like this for me, not just deckbuilders.) Dicey Dungeons is simple and snackable, so if you like it, expect high replay value.

Enthusiastic recommendation from me! Not going to be worth every single person's time - it depends on their taste! But most people will like playing this game.

Un girito muy refrescante a los roguelites de cartas con su propia personalidad.

Puede parecer algo tonto o demasiado sencillo al comienzo, pero conforme avanzas por los capítulos las mecánicas presentadas va adquiriendo una complejidad o dificultad mucho más estimulante; mientras que, conforme desbloqueas personajes, prácticamente experimentas mecánicas y formas de jugar totalmente nuevas que reavivan la frescura del juego una y otra vez.

Por otro lado, en cuanto a la presentación, el arte es muy cuco, con un tono burlón, desenfadado y sencillo, con mucho encanto. Y la música está genial, es muy marchosa y pegadiza.

En resumen, un juego notable. Muy divertido, tanto para viciarse durante horas, como para jugar partidas cortas y esporádicas. También es muy accesible en cuanto al precio, especialmente en rebajas. 119007828.review:
Dicey Dungeons is awesome, it's not the most widely complex game ever but it's got a very strong format with addictive and rewarding gameplay. What makes it so much fun is the turn based moment to moment combat, It's all mainly about managing your health and turns. The core gameplay is going through a randomly generated set of levels which consist of enemies shops and some special events. Entering combat is what the bulk of the content is, you face off from a large selection of enemies with all varied ways of attacking in combat. They all feel quite balanced and well designed. Where the roguelike elements come into the game is the weapon loadouts, you can customise your weapon kit by finding new attacks or buying them from the shops. The big feature in this game is the dice, each turn you use your dice to play your attacks this could be rolling a six onto an attack and also using other dice to play other moves in your loadout. This gameplay is very fun and addictive because of its random nature. On the other hand this game has been criticised for its randomised gameplay design. As for this i'd certainly say if you don't like RNG or random gameplay elements i would outright not play this game however if you can accept this randomness, this game is very enjoyable. Out of the actual game/missions you have a selection of characters to choose from. All having unique starting loadouts and interesting gameplay features to keep your runs interesting. The other core part of the out of game content is the “episodes” each character has a total of 6 episodes to play which progress the overall story and unlock new gameplay modifiers. Other gameplay features include achievements and other small nice additions. 

The art in the game is solid, I feel this game's visuals speak for themself, it's all extremely well crafted, it looks very charming and it's always great seeing new locations and character designs. The soundtrack for this game is very unique and awesome, it has a line up of all kinds of great songs, nothing really genre focused but they all fit the cartoony and lighthearted tone. As for bugs there were none, I have nothing to say on that front, it played extremely well the whole time and had not a single issue. The performance is also not an issue here; the game was just brought to IOS and Android devices. It requires literally any specs within the last 10 years to play this game, it runs very well. 

In conclusion this game is a solid roguelike which helped define the genre in many ways, the game also has recently added a whole new update called “reunion” with a new set of episodes which further adds to its value. The game has a solid amount of content and unique gameplay and I fully recommend it if you like deck builders, roguelikes or turn-based games.

118997797.review:
This game is very cute!

The player takes the role of an adventurous game die, rolling its way through a kooky dungeon filled with pun-based monsters and collecting various "equipment" that can be used to defeat said monsters. The colors are vivid and the music feels like one very long k-pop instrumental bridge.

It's no cakewalk, especially once the more challenging dice-types are unlocked, but everything is tactical and it is completely possible to optimize your little adventurer and find synergistic combos of equipment, or carefully plan your route through a dungeon to avoid being defeated before the boss fight.

It's the kind of game that I'm happy to throw a quick attempt at once a week, and if I don't make the cut, no big deal. If I beat a level, then I get new content for next time! I will probably never 100% this kind of game, but it's fun enough to spend an half hour with here and there.

The only reason this game doesn't get 10/10 from me is because of Witch. 118967741.review:
Dicey Dungeons itself is a pretty good game, definitely above average in this price bracket and genre and I highly recommend it. It's a sort of turn-based puzzle deck builder-lite where the strategy elements mostly flow around manipulations of/workarounds to luck (dice rolls, mainly). The majority of runs will also have you managing a small deck of ability cards but there's no sort of meta progression and your decks and available card pool change entirely from challenge to challenge.

The game itself is structured and linear, there's no perpetual mode or procedural generation - it's absolutely more of a puzzle game than anything resembling a roguelike although failing in a run will reset your progress in that challenge to the beginning. There is no global progression aside from clearing each of the 6 challenges for each of the handful of characters. Challenges typically consist of a run through the dungeon of 5 stages + a boss stage. The character you choose loosely determines their playstyle, with the various challenges all adding a twist to their gimmick to work through.

If I had to give it demerits, it's really just that you're going to feel like most of the challenges end right when they're just getting going. There's no perpetual mode, no meta progression and a great many of the "builds" the game has you work through really only begin to piece together on floor 5 of a given "run" and right after that it's over. This is a puzzle game, not something you will perpetually return to. Once you're done with it, it's going on the shelf until DLC comes out. This isn't a bad thing, just don't expect something different. That said, it's still good fun and has its fair share of surprises in store for you so if it sounds at all appealing to you, give it a try.

That all said, Dicey Dungeons the OST is immaculate. This game has probably the best soundtrack of any game I've played in years, a  top 10 all time for me for sure. Chipzel's work here blending the sort of big band jazzy music you hear in game show intros with thumping, driving, dancing chiptune beats and melodies is just nothing short of genius. And if you weren't certain whether or not it was genius or accident they did it again in the recent DLC update, absolute home run of a soundtrack, just outstanding work. You will get these songs stuck with you, and simply the prospect of hearing them will keep you invested in finishing this one.

I had to remove my last review for this game the second I beat it to update it with a new one because this game deserves SO MUCH BETTER than that short review of mine.

This game is SIMPLE yet fun. All the mechanics are built around dice and playing it really hits home to the feel of playing a tabletop game. The game itself is technically "short", but the replayability is HIGH. This game also keep on giving with the free DLCs such as the Halloween and the most recent Reunion update.

The art style is simple yet charming. The UI is very clean. The voice act is amazing and the music is such a jam I couldn't get it out from my head even if I try. The story also keep the same simplicity and it's very appealing in its way.

Each character in this game have its own gimmick with some is actually trickier to figure out on how to use. Each character have several episodes and each episodes also serves with its own spin that each can be replayed separatedly. Every single time you think you got this game or character figured out, each new episode will always bring out a fresh new spin and you'll have to relearn and restrategize again. The challenge is keep on giving. Sometimes the game can be very luck-based. But the devs obviously knew this that they allow the option to quit and reopening the game at any point.

The game is very small in size and it's packaged with full of fun.
Highly recommended for everyone looking for a good strategy roguelike game or into it in general. For those who aren't exactly into this genre this game might hit a bit too hard especially with some characters and episodes, but you can still get a lot of fun even when you're replaying one same episode.

Props to the devs. Very good game and thank you so much for delivering this amazing game to us. Will be awaiting any new content or game you're giving us.

118664922.review:
This is basically [I]Yahtzee: The Roguelike[/I] with really cute art and just the right amount of depth for its bite-sized nature.  The agency comes in on two dimensions: deciding which equipment to equip (which determines which dice you can place and what happens when you do so); and deciding which equipment to activate and in which order from turn to turn and encounter to encounter.

The buildcraft is somewhat limited in most episodes by a small pool of divergence (e.g., the chest on floor 1 will always have either X or Y), but eventually there are modes where anything goes.  In any case, this game is also eminently moddable, and there's a pretty big library of mods on itch.io for expanding beyond the base experience.

Definitely recommend playing through casually--I don't know whether this runs on Steam Deck, but if it does it's a perfect candidate for a "whenever you have a few moments" game.  It's worth the full price, but if you're strapped for cash it also pops up on ridiculous sale from time to time.

In conclusion, Baby Squid 4 Lyfe!

118588000.review:
Its weird giving a thumbs up to a game I did not really like, it definitely will have appeal to the right player, and I did get a good number of hours out of it despite not really being a fan.

Pick your class, unlock new challenges and parts of the story as you go, fight monsters in a dungeon while you collect gear and work your way to the boss. Your gear interacts with simple d6s in a variety of ways from the obvious of the higher roll is better, to the lower roll is better, to very interesting minimum and maxium, even and odd, or spliting, flipping, and changing dice. With a variety of status effects. 

The game-play is far to simple for my taste, but that being said it is clean, polished, has plenty of content, and provides challenge.

Enemies have arbitrary immunities and elemental weaknesses and strengths, which generally I find to be one of the worst ways of designing encounters, but that being said you get a collection of gear that you can freely swap out as you need, so as long as you plan ahead the system is actually just fine.

The story is kind of weird and silly and definitely not to my taste, but that is not a bad thing they pull off exactly what they are trying to do. 

There are very few decisions to make as you can fully explore each dungeon and usually buy everything you want. The only real choices come up on every few level ups when you need to pick between two options, and of course how to use your dice each turn. But that being said keeping the focus on the combat and a couple important choices can be nice rather than the common trope of "the run was lost before you started" theme in most roguelites.

I did not really enjoy any of the classes, the first one was decent but very boring, and I actively disliked the rest of them. That being said there is a great deal of variety and each class feels unique and interesting. 

The game is very RNG reliant much more than I like, but it is both a dice game and a roguelite so I mean if you are getting this game that is exactly what you are after and it delivers well.

This is one of the best, way before the rush to roguelike card games made by mid mtg commander players that have zip zero zilch qualia in their meme soaked catbrains renditions of a take on solitaire I have seen in the modern day.

While I think my pappy slapping kings on the poker table in some kind of effort to take back what a thousand hoes took from him may have given him a esoteric pique into the fabric of humanity itself as it renders itself through cost based triangles this is different but on the same level. Not only does the dice mechanic in this game slap harder them he did a fifth through 10% off bushmills from Safeway the soundtrack makes Deontay WIlder some how done in real life super attacks look like baby slaps on a sloppy food table. The jazzy funk flat out bops.

This game has the dedication of a person who has seen their dark night of the soul, wondering if their work is just as useless as an "im so sorry we are robbing you" tier one customer service rep. It has the energy of someone who genuinely wants you to have a fun time.

AND THIS GUY MADE LITERALLY A SECOND DLC?

You owe it to yourself to play this game and sell your mid commander deck. When the glue dies in beta cards the market will crash anyways, and you will be stuck playing every bad version of concrete worn digital renditions of nostalgia long dead rendered through the perfectly delicate hands of noodle armed programmers anyways.

As a man made almost entirely of trans fat and dictionaries this has given me a sublime satisfaction.

117758072.review:
I am a great lover of Magic the Gathering but haven't played many video cards games besides Slay the Spire. Dicey Dungeon came to my attention and I thought it looked quite fun and it can be. This game amazed me with how much variety there is. 

Each character plays entirely differently from the others. On top of that, there are different rule sets you can apply to each run that drastically change the way things are played for each character. It took me nearly forty hours just to run through each scenario once, which is a staggering amount of content for variety in runs in a rogue like. 

That being said, I would say that this game isn't for everyone because it isn't always for me. One of the big issues I have with this game is the same I had with Slay the Spire, the frustrating lack of consistency during deck building. Going back to the top of this review, I am a huge fan of magic the gathering, I get that runs in rogue likes are meant to live and die by RNG but that doesn't always mesh well with what makes a card game fun. 

Card games have RNG as well but that comes during the games, not during deck construction. While the extent that Dicey Dungeons feels exactly like a card game has some variety depending on the character and you know for sure, with most characters, what cards you'll have in your hand each turn the fact that you can't always get a load out you enjoy makes some runs a real slough. I found myself having to often pick between what would win and what I would find fun. 

Still, over all, I greatly enjoyed my time with Dicey Dungeon and I wouldn't actually change anything about it. I can recognise that being able to design the exact load out/deck I want each run would trivialise any challenge that the game can offer since you could just build the best deck. But I felt it was worth noting what might keep others from enjoying this game on top of what was absolutely amazing about it which is everything else. Heck, I didn't even touch on the story or characters both of which were full of life and humour that added just enough to add to experience without becoming overbearing from what, at the end of the day, is a satisfying core game-play loop that balances strategy and chance exceptionally well.

117226630.review:
Dicey Dungeons is a creator's exercise in pushing dice mechanics to the absolute brink while still maintaining simplicity. This game is amazing if you've ever dabbled in dice based board games. You play the role of an adventurer trying to get through a dungeon. Warrior, Thief, and Witch are all present plus a few unusual inclusions. The goal is to go through a semi-random dungeon while gaining levels, getting equipment, and then toppling a boss. It sounds simple enough but the thing that really sets this game apart is the sheer amount of instantly readable dice mechanics. Nearly everything in the game revolves around six sided die. Not just your equipment but the enemy's as well. To go along with this, every character also has six versions of the dungeon to go through. They can be minor differences at first but some go so hard in the other direction that it feels like you're playing an entirely different character against completely different enemies all confined to a single chapter. Strange side rules get tacked on to up the challenge culminating in a steady climb in difficulty.

 Some characters are easier to understand than others but I wouldn't necessarily use the game's metrics to measure it. I personally had a very difficult time wrapping my head around the Inventor's mentality while the Witch, most commonly referred to as the most confusing, felt challenging but easy enough to understand. Now, if you don't like RNG in games, you'd be surprised at how enjoyable this one can be. I think the RPG mechanics of picking equipment that suits your own ideas of randomness help curb the effect. You could have crazy builds where you'll be devastating on 6's or have builds that allow you to forge a specific thing to happen nearly every turn. A standard run isn't too lengthy either with a endlessly replayable soundtrack to rise in intensity and catchiness the further you delve. 

Despite all my praise, I'll say it did take me a lengthy chunk of time to beat this game. I was very opposed to using any sort of exploit or guide to win and one character in particular felt exceedingly difficult to play if you were missing a specific piece of equipment. I would put the game down then pick it back up years later. The fact that I can still remember the mechanics so well is a testament to the strength of the designs within the game. It will be slightly frustrating at times but the presentation doesn't let you dwell on losses at all. Definitely the mark of a great game.

116551897.review:
A game with hilarious writing and even character development (the twist final character blew me away), a fantastic villain, beautiful art, and that drips with love and attention to detail throughout.  No minutia was overlooked, which you'll truly respect in the final run.
All that can only go so far however, and this game is elevated to stardom by its tight and varied gameplay.  You'll play with only two "standard" characters before being thrown into runs with those who fundamentally change the rules of the game, and three who will require a completely different strategic perspective from the prior half of the roster.  Fellow players of Magic: the Gathering I think will appreciate the secret final character, who [spoiler]rewards cantripping dice and multiplicity of equipment[/spoiler].  I'd say my preference is, from highest to lowest: [spoiler]Jester...Robot...Witch......Fighter...Inventor......Thief[/spoiler].  Truly highlighting the game's dedication to variety are the entirely different ways to play relegated to a single game mode.
I cannot recommend this game enough.  My only complaint is that the second and fourth characters can be less fun than the others.  The fourth forces you to take a different approach than the others, which is appreciated but can wear thin at times, while the second character's second mission can be punishingly difficult.  Some players may find the learning curve of the fifth character a bit steep, as well, but she's quite fun once you're acquainted with her.

116059288.review:
A Slay the Spire-like game, which features manipulating 6-sided dice rolls, equipment, and class bonuses to defeat a five-level dungeon under a myriad of different scenarios.

The game features six classes, ranging from the very straightforward fighter, who is looking to put large dice in sword weapons, and has a reroll skill to help turn small dice into large dice; to the robot, who has a CPU meter that fills with each die that's rolled, and equipment that gets stronger the more dice have been rolled that turn... but don't overload your CPU, or all your skills fizzle; to the witch, who can memorize six spells, which can then be called out and used.

Unlike Slay the Spire, you always have access to all the equipment on your character - a 3 x 4 grid that's filled with either 1x2 or 1x4 pieces of equipment - the trick is to use the dice you've rolled most efficiently with what you've got.

There's a bunch of different equipment, which has effects ranging from direct damage, to elemental effects, to shielding, to healing, to dice manipulation and more; all of which falls under three different categories: items that take only certain dice (ie needs a 6), items that take any dice (ie will take a 1-6), and items that have countdowns before they activate (ie needs 12 points worth of dice). All equipment can be upgraded, either increasing damage, removing dice restrictions, changing a 1x4 equipment into a 1x2 equipment (allowing you to wield more items), or a combination of the above.

Health is restored through three methods: in-combat, through items; out of combat, by collecting apples in the dungeon or by buying apples that appear in shops; and by leveling up, which gives a full heal. Managing your health is by far the most intricate part of the game, deciding when you'll need to grab an extra apple before a fight, and when it's best to tough it out to save it for later.

The game features charming graphics and music, going for a lighter dungeon crawling experience.

My only notable complaint about the game is that the dungeons are arranged so that there are exactly enough monsters so that you can only max out your level if you kill everything. Because the bonuses of leveling up (extra dice and/or equipment, plus the full heal) are so great, you're pretty much obligated to kill everything, even if the monster doesn't block your progress, or you'd rather leave a more difficult enemy alone.

Overall - well worth picking up.

116016044.review:
It is fun while it lasts. I enjoy these types of games, but a major recurring theme for their design is that the RNG can be mitigated through good decisions made throughout the run. It is possible that this game has that, and I am just missing it, but after 12 hours, I am not sure that is the case. It is disappointing because the game is very very close to being exactly what I desire from this whole "roguelike deckbuilding" thing that has blown up in the last few years. The elements are all there, but they're not quite to scale, and the randomness tends to ruin the parts that are really good. The maps are small, and there is little variety to the level design (though the art throughout the entire game is pretty damn great). Often, the floor consists of a few battles and a store (which only offers you 3 items to buy).

The game is structured through "episodes", which are increasingly difficult runs with different challenge modifiers added to the run. This was quite enjoyable as I was forced to change how I played in order to consistently win. This stayed true until the third episode (I had this problem with all characters around this episode). The difficulty ramp-up was so stark that it outran the ability to outplay the RNG. The game does not offer much choice variety in what equipment you receive throughout your run, and that makes it particularly difficult to mitigate bad rolls. You get just a few of those, and you've gone from full health to one quarter, in just a single battle. There were many times where I would die to the very first enemy on the second floor, and there was no way to stop it. In a particularly bad instance, I died to the second enemy on the first floor. Up until that battle, there was only one available chest, and it would always have one of two possible pieces of equipment (many times I died on the second floor after only reaching one chest too). Neither of those equipment pieces do anything to help actually win the battle. In this particular instance, I would almost always get one that gave you an extra gold piece at the end of battle. 

There were no decisions being made by me that would affect whether or not I died, and that was a problem for me. More generally, there are only a few variables that you can even change up in regards to pathing and equipment choice. When there were options, and I would die, I would pick the other option on the next try, only to die again due to the RNG of both of our dice, as well as both of our debuffs. When you feel that your agency as a player has been taken away, you tend to not enjoy the experience at all. And I can't recommend an experience that makes me feel like I'm at the whims of randomness.

I would so love to be wrong, so if you are actually really good at the game, please comment and let me know what I'm missing. I could use another game in this vein to dump hundreds of hours into getting good at, and I thought this might be the one when I bought it.

Pros-
=Super fast pickup, the game is super simple, you have dice, the dice do things when you put them into equipment, beat the boss at the bottom of three floors.
=Cute artstyle, totally my opinion but I love the designs
=Varied gameplay between each of the characters, with different styles of gameplay to master, and the curve you take can be as gentle a slope as you want

Cons

I know that's weird to put as a con, I just think that it's a little hard not to point it out as you can get to the end of a good run and your dice decide to roll low at the worst possible moment, which means that your victories may not in fact, rely on skillful decision making.

UPDATE:
Not changing the status, but there are things you should know.
1. What you roll is determined before you start a battle.
2. Exiting during a battle lets you start over with the same roll. If you want a different roll, change the equipment around in any way.
3. The rolls for the enemies are similarly predetermined.

Does this detract from the feeling of accomplishment? Yes. Does it make me even more frustrated with how stacked some of the challenges are? Also yes.

114049272.review:
Absolutely delightful.

Dicey Dungeon is a roguelike card battler with dice. It may not be for everyone as it's inherently less complex and strategic than, say, Slay the Spire, but it has many selling points none the less. The main one is the incredible level of polish. You have a total of six playable characters (5 have to be unlocked) that each play very differently. And each character has six episodes to beat. (seven if you include the hard version of the sixth). And again these different episodes each introduce something that dramatically changes the game. Some of the six episodes are similar to episodes for other characters (like the one that cranks up the difficulty by giving your foes improved equipment) but others are tailor-made for that particular character.

All this makes for a game that is highly replayable (and you'll need to beat at least five episodes per character if you want to reach the true ending anyway) while rarely being frustrating (if you're struggling against a particular episode, chances are you have at least a couple of others unlocked that you can try instead.).

Some people have complained that the dice make the game too random. This is only partly true. Once you "get" the game, you can almost always manage your equipment to mitigate your own luck of the dice. But it's true that occasionally, in the most difficult episodes, a monster may roll a particularly lucky set of dice that will leave you little chance to get out of the battle alive. But each run is short enough that the frustration is kept in check.

You won't be surprised then that I highly recommend Dicey Dungeons.

112980397.review:
This is not a straight up recommendation but more like it kinda depends kind of deal.

Dicey dungeons at the core is a simple game. Choose a character, an episode, then make your way through the dungeon to the boss fight and win. Each character has it's own way of wanting to play, equipment and rules for episodes in a semi-rng way. But whether you have fun or not really depends on, if you enjoy the play style of the characters. Time flies when you're having fun, but you'll feel like in a time vacuum when it's a character you don't. 

Now why I can't really recommend the game to everyone, is that 4 out of 6 episodes have the exact same rules set for every character. So there isn't as much variety as it looks like on the surface. But that's not all. Equipment for the large part is also the same within an episode. So if you fail and retry, you'll probably get the exact same equipment at the same/similar point within the dungeon. Which means the main difference maker outside of your decision making, then it's the RNG of the dice rolls. Having a run that's going well? One big RNG swing in one fight can ruin an entire run and that'll be 20 mins down the drain. 

Okay, let's quickly more onto what's good. The art style is nice, the music is absolutely great, when you enjoy a character you'll feel like you have flown through it's content and when the game is on sale it's usually quite cheap. If you subscribe to the 1 dollar/pound/euro etc = 1 hour of game length, then you are certainly gonna get more than your money's worth. 

In the end, I would say Dicey Dungeons is a fine game and whether you should buy it or not depends how okay are you with RNG of the dice and that you'll probably won't like the play style of each character. If you want the game, pick it up during a sale and you pretty much can't go wrong with it.

111726307.review:
8.5/10

The core idea is so great that I made my own board game with similar mechanics. Rolling dice to use certain cards from your deck is a genius idea and I absolutely love it. What I hated, however, were some very specific parts that just made me hate 20% of my experience.

Each of the six characters have unique mechanics and six "chapters" to complete (+6 Hard mode chapters), totaling 42 runs you have to complete to beat the main game. There are also plenty of achievements you can go for, which unlock some trivia for each enemy you encounter in the dungeon. Reading through the monsters' info gives life and meaning to what would otherwise seem like random enemies that mostly don't fit in a dungeon scenario. The art style is probably my favorite part of the game. Each character can seem cutesy and threatening at the same time, and they all make for memorable encounters. Each enemy is so unique that they each have their own move set, trading off balancing and consistency for a really varied experience from run to run.

Now, here comes my biggest problem with the game. It can be unfair at times, killing a 20-30 minute run due to poor RNG. At least this was my experience with it. Certain characters just don't have the consistency necessary to form win streaks, but I guess that isn't a huge deal. The main problem lies in chapter 4 of every character. In it, with any of the characters, enemies get all their equipment upgraded and 10% extra health. That's cool and all until you get to some absolutely insane fights (ie. Sneezy and Cowboy Cat) that are sometimes outright impossible to win. I wish Chapter 4 got a revision where fights were harder and that didn't mean every equipment was simply upgraded.

Apart from Chapter 4 I also hated the Witch. That's probably because I'm just bad when playing with her, but also due to the completely different gameplay style. When playing as the Witch, you must to prepare spells before using them instead of just having your hand available each turn, making fights way slower and consequently turning damage mitigation way tougher than with any other character. Half of my playtime (not kidding) is probably just Witch gameplay, which includes hours and hours of failure and resentment.

With all of that said, this game isn't bad at all. It's hell trying to go for all the achievements and having to deal with insane odds, but the rest of the game (about 80% of content, 50-60% of playtime) is mostly pure joy. Having to decide on the fly what to do with the dice you rolled is really really fun. The constant feeling of winning and losing gambles makes for an exciting and unique experience that I have only experienced with this game. You can always play Poker, but it doesn't have nearly as much personality as this game. I simply love most characters and can easily see myself coming back to do some random runs in the future. For now, however, I'm pretty much done with this game and I can say it was worth playing.

Oh, and the soundtrack is amazing by the way.

Graphics: 10/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Enjoyment: 7.5/10
Soundtrack: 9.5/10
Recommend? Yes

This review was made right after achieving 100% achievements. (53/53)

If you think seximal is the best number system then stop reading reviews and buy this game now, you'll love it.

Dicey Dungeons was way better than I expected! When this game came out, the teaser looked like just another generic roguelike, 
nothing Slay the Spire hadn't done already. I was pleasantly surprised -- the yahtzee-esque mechanics are incredibly polished, and different from anything I've seen before.

What really makes this game stand out is the episode system! Instead of just throwing content in a blender, the game has thirty-six distinct episodes, each with a curated selection of weapons, enemies, and gimmicks unique to that episode. It's the 'themed worlds and stages' concept that works so well for platformers, now applied to a turn-based strategy game! Plus, this gives the game just enough narrative structure for it to have a meaningful ending. Imagine that! A roguelike with an ending!

This game delivers an awesome amount of fun-per-minute, and doesn't overstay its welcome. If you like dice, then what are you waiting for?

En otra reseña exhaustiva indican que para los que estén acostumbrados a jugarlos, este juego resultará aburrido a las pocas horas debido a su facilidad... por suerte, este ha sido mi segundo roguelike jamás jugado, así que para nada me he sentido por encima del nivel de reto, creo, de hecho, que es una forma divertida de probar el género sin frustrarte por el nivel de exigencia: puedes ir poco a poco, pensar cada movimiento, crear varias estrategias y probar modos de juego diferentes gracias a los personajes que vas desbloqueando, cada uno con habilidades únicas.

En ese sentido, lo encuentro un jueguito divertido, mono y una experiencia divertida para jugar con amigos más listos que tú (pro tip: ¡no les hagas caso siempre! ¡Sigue a tu corazón! ¡Oye sus gritos de frustración y siente la adrenalina!); si eres el amigo listo, prueba a regalárselo a alguien a quien le quieras enseñar el género, probablemente jugando con esa persona le saques unas risas a un juego que, de otro modo, puede parecerte demasiado fácil.

Más allá del tema de la dificultad, tiene lo que promete: un sentido del humor ligero (aunque un poco repetitivo) y una traducción que lo mantiene, unos gráficos lindos, y un porrón de niveles que pasarse con diversas penalizaciones que hacen que el juego se vuelva más interesante según se avanza.

No es un 10/10, ni el juego que te va a cambiar la vida, pero creo que tampoco pretende serlo. Para mí es un juego al que echarle un ratito cuando quiero estar relajada pero entretenida con algo, y eso lo cumple a la perfección.

111533891.review:
This game (and all of Terry's games frankly) is an absolute treasure. If you love MTG, slay the spire type games, or rolling dice: 

This is your game.

It's such a beautifully simply concept, roll dice, use dice, try not to die. But in that simplicity Terry has crafted 6 deliciously unique characters. Each one maintains the basic concept with a fun themed twist, never overwhelmingly complicated while still adding hours upon hours to the game. While a run may last 5-30+ minutes, you can save and continue your journey on a whim, making it the perfect game for a round or two during lunch. The art style and music is fun enough to have on without getting annoying, while also maintaining a playful atmosphere if you listen to something else while you play. 

Some specific points I like:
[list]
[*] The enemies keep their same movesets between characters, meaning you only have to figure out the new quirk for each episode
[*] Each character (and all their episodes) have multiple loadouts that are completely viable, there's never just one method
[*] The parallel universe episodes are such a blast that it genuinely feels like 6 alternative full versions of the game! an already amazing game!
[*] I adore the enemies and their personalities, for the first several hours it's very fun to meet them, and I love the family type atmosphere they have together, it feels like we're all friends trapped in hell for eternity
[*] The random layouts for each floor have enough variety that you can build the same setup 6 times in a row without feeling like you're playing the exact same way 6 times in a row
[/list]

TL;DR [b]BUY IT[/b]

On a serious note though, this is one of the best games I've played. Prepare yourself I'm about to go on a bit of a unproofread rant. It's nothing special and very simple, all the enemies are very one-note personalities and the contestants don't get enough to say, but I will always love how distinct their traits are! 
A social media star who might have attention issues is the most luck based and hard to play character? Sure!
A workaholic who wants to discard it's basic living needs so it can push itself to the limit having it's mechanic being blackjack, where if you push yourself too far you can't use your items anymore? That's pretty cool!
A genius scatterbrain who gets distracted easily constantly discarding equipments to turn into gadgets that also get discarded? Honestly some of the best autism/adhd rep I've seen

Basically, the game is not for everyone. You love it or you hate it. But there's still a lot to enjoy about Dicey, even if its not the *perfect* game.

110903378.review:
Dicey Dungeons is the latest, and arguably most obscure, release from Terry Cavanagh, who you may know for creating two of the most renowned indie games of the 2010s; VVVVVV and Super Hexagon. Whilst Dicey Dungeons has relatively minimalist presentation like his previous releases, the gameplay is much more complex. It adapts the template of the roguelike deckbuilding genre, which already involves random elements relating to enemies and equipment, and adding an additional layer of RNG on top with dice rolling, creating a game which could be appropriately described as RNGception. However, while luck may not always be in your favour, the game gives you lots of opportunities to turn the tide.

The goal of each episode/level is to get to the bottom floor of a dungeon and defeat the boss within, whilst building up equipment and dealing with a random selection of enemies along the way. You start by playing as the Warrior, one of six playable characters, who’s first equipment is a sword which deals damage according to the number on the dice used, and you have the option to re-roll your dice up to three times per turn. Defeating an enemy will grant you with exp and coins, the former which awards you with extra dice to use per turn whilst healing you to full health, and the latter allows you to buy extra equipment from the shops randomly placed within each run. On paper, this will sound very simple, but there are so many variables which keeps this game fresh and challenging even when replaying the same levels 40 hours in, and this review will serve to illustrate the substantial variety on offer.

Staring with equipment, some pieces simply benefit from having the highest roll to deal the most damage, but in many cases, this will be detrimental. Some equipment only works with even or odd rolls, some require dice totalling a specific number to be inputted before activation, and so on. One basic synergy involves equipment which is guaranteed to re-roll either an odd or even dice, and then selecting damaging equipment which only works with such rolls. There are also equipment pieces which deal status effect damage that are crucial to help win the most difficult fights. For example, using equipment that induces freeze will change the highest roll of your opponents turn to a one which will significantly slow down the damage output of most enemies.

However, freeze damage is not always advisable, as there are specific enemies which will benefit from having frozen dice. The snowman has equipment which deals freeze damage with an odd numbered dice, and so using such equipment on them is guaranteed to backfire. Fire damage would be better here, as this will burn some dice which require a health cost so they can be used that turn, and such enemies will take double damage from this source. To name just one of the remaining effects, ‘weaken’ makes all affected equipment less powerful for one turn, either temporarily removing certain effects, or changing the dice requirements to be more constricted. Furthermore, each status has an alternate version which results in the effects of these statuses changing; freeze damage will instead decrease all dice in your hand by one value per infliction, and burnt dice will disable any equipment it is used on for the next turn. 

For an even more substantial gameplay change, look no further than the remaining five characters on offer, each of which drastically change how you play the game. For example, the thief starts with equipment which only works with low value dice, so one effective setup would involve using equipment which splits up high value dice, alongside equipment which can be activated by multiple dice per turn. My personal favourite character is the robot which completely changes how you receive dice, requiring you to earn it from a slot machine which will shut down your equipment for the turn if a value limit is surpassed. This is supported best with equipment that decreases the increase rate of that value limit, alongside equipment which deals more damage the more dice you roll that turn. However, if you hit the value limit on the dot, you’ll receive an additional ability for that turn, and there are many supporting pieces of equipment which improve your chances of using it. This is the character which I think most effectively demonstrates this game's greatest achievement, in that its entire concept is centred around multiple layers of randomness, yet has plentiful equipment synergies which allow you to turn even the most unhelpful dice rolls into a good amount of damage per turn. 

The final area which adds variety comes from the per-episode modifiers. You’ll only have one episode per character where the rules remain standard, giving you an opportunity to learn how they work. After that, you’ll have to deal with additional challenges which will really test your ability to create the best out of a bad situation. Each character has six episodes, two of which are specific to that character, for example setting your dice rolls so that you will always roll a 6, then a 5 and so on, or giving you really powerful items whilst dealing with the handicap that all equipment used can fail at random. It’s best to think of these episodes as puzzles, as you will need to create a build that deals with the limitations set by the modifiers. While there is a bit less freedom in terms of effective builds here, they are definitely worthwhile experiences for the first run-through. Each character’s final episode involves receiving four random modifiers per run per floor of the dungeon, which can range from somewhat beneficial to your current build, to absolutely devastating changes that will require you to change up your approach mid-run. There are also episodes solely dedicated to alternate status modifiers, and it is possible that a modifier will show up in the final episode that will switch the statuses to this version.

There isn’t much more to the game aside from the core episode progression, but that’s definitely not a negative considering its small scope. There is a basic narrative that directs you to complete each episode, and is worth experiencing to its conclusion as there is an excellent final boss sequence which made all the time spent worth it. Completing it on my first attempt was incredibly satisfying, though it did take me 30 hours to get there as you have to complete the final levels for each character. Your mileage will vary depending on your skill, some luck, and how much you decide to essentially save scum the experience. It is possible to exit out of a battle that isn’t going your way, and reload to see if you can get luckier the next time around. I admit I got a bit frustrated near completion of the game; in my first 15 or so hours, I would simply restart the episode from the beginning as opposed to save scumming due to the solid gameplay loop. However, some of my final hours were spent reloading and eventually conceding to what were essential brick walls with some enemies, not having just the right conditions that would allow me to survive.

Despite this later frustration, I can confidently say that Dicey Dungeons is one of the most enjoyable completion experiences I’ve had with an indie game in a long while. I barely grew tired of it even when it felt like the game hated me, and I got more than my money’s worth getting this at a 75% discount. I would definitely recommend this even at full price if you’re open to a unique experience, but only if you are willing to face its requirements and adapt to the RNGception on display here. I’m very much looking forward to Terry’s next title.

110645726.review:
Quick Description:
-Dicey Dungeon takes everything that you know about deckbuilders and throws it out the window, by adding dice into the mix.  It's a surprisingly fun, challenging, and strategic turn-based adventure.  You can expect slightly more variance/rng than the typical game, but that's to be expected anytime dice mechanics are added in.  

What's Good:
-The skill ceiling is quite high, which is great.  Deciding which cards to purchase, which cards to upgrade, when to play cards, and where to use your cards are all extremely important decisions.  Even though the dice plays a role in the game, the choices you make is far more important over the course of many runs.
-There are 6 different unlockable characters, and each one has a very unique playstyle that really mixes up the game.  This was a brilliant choice b/c every character changes the fabric of the game so much, making it really exciting to unlock a new character.  I unlocked the first 5 characters and found the Inventor to be my favorite character by far.
-There is so much charm and love in this game!  The story is simple, but adorable and hilarious.  The dev clearly has a good sense of humor, and created a world filled w/ funny characters, interesting philosophical dilemmas, and bright visuals.  
-The deckbuilding elements of this game are solid.  Every starting dice has a different set of cards and there are a good amount of cards to purchase throughout your run.  The cards give a lot of freedom to different playstyles such as higher dps builds, more defensive builds, or more status effect heavy builds.  You will instantly have full access to all of your cards, as there are no cards to unlock.
-This is a great game for both casuals and deckbuilder fanatics.  The Warrior is the starting dice and is by far the simplest to learn and become competent.  Mastering this character lays the foundation for future characters.  The Witch is the fifth character and is by far the most complex dice to use.  I'm really looking forward to future runs w/ the witch.

Could Use Some Changes:
-As to be expected, any time a dice is involved, there will inevitably be some variance or rng.  It's really frustrating when a boss needs to roll a specific number and somehow he rolls that several times in a row.  Of course, we as people tend to overlook when the dice favors us, and only focus on when the dice favors someone else.  Nonetheless, this is still worth mentioning. 
-The lack of meta progression is probably my biggest disappointment.  Unlocking the first 5 dice is really easy and will be done in 3-4 hrs.  As far as I'm aware, the Jester is the last unlockable thing in the game (There is also a secret unlockable Bear dice).  Meta progression is an extremely valuable tool to help motivate players to come back for more, so I would have loved to see more ways to unlock new cards, blueprints, or dice.
-Dicey Dungeons lacks the depth of the very best of this genre.  I can't imagine that many players will want to play this for hundreds of hrs, where as that is extremely common in top tier deckbuilders.  I'd say this is slightly more casual experience than the typical game in this genre.

Consensus:
-Solid Game (Tier 3 and makes up 35% of my reviews).  I wasn't sure if I would enjoy this game, b/c I'm not a big fan of dice games.  At least I thought I wasn't.  I guess I am now, but this was a really fun experience.  The silly and fun loving atmosphere was the perfect tone for a game like this.  I will definitely be coming back sometime soon to master a few of the other dice and hopefully unlock the Jester.  If you are itching for a creative and original take on the deckbuilder genre, then Dicey Dungeon may just be for you.

110070906.review:
I'm a big fan of Terry Cavanagh's games and this one to me is no exception.

You pick a contestant at the start; each dice has it's own difficulty based off their abilities and potential pickups.
Then you pick a door, each with their own ruleset/changes.
The meat of the game is basically getting to the bottom floor of each dungeon and defeating its boss. To do that, you need to get to the trapdoor of each floor, defeat the enemies (defeating all is optional, but rewarded), collect/buy new weapons and formulate your strategy as you go.

I've heard some people complain about the RNG in this game but I think you can have a great deal of control over this if you play to what each challenge is trying to do; there is still some really good and rotten luck beyond that but let's be realistic for a moment; it's a game about dice. :p

There are some very clever ideas in this game and some creative (but always quite easy) powers and abilities to use and come across - nothing is ever too complicated to understand, even in the later doors where the rules are somewhat tipped on their head, (no spoilers), I do wish though that some of the later powers in the last couple of doors were introduced earlier, there is some really cool stuff that may not get seen if you give up in the mid-early game due to difficulty, but I can also see why they weren't mixed up in the early sections as well.

Music and SFX are ok; nothing special but nothing bad either; and there are special unlocks along the way and an overarching sort-of story that is going on in the background as well.

SUMMARY
When I first started this game, I found that I put it away quickly because I thought it was limited in scope and variance - door 4 on each is a bit of a show-stopper due to its difficulty and I didn't bother with doors 5-6.
Then I came back to it because my 5yr old son was interested and I found a new life to it and along with that,  more ideas opened up, more strategies and doors 5-6 were brand new games to me and I've kept playing it since.
Well worth the price, plenty of time to sink into it but doesn't take much time to casually play it either.
This games works for me as an after-work game, get a drink ready, some Spoitfy and then relax and get into it.

109621383.review:
Dicey Dungeons is an approachable, charming deck builder where the player is expected to focus on leveraging their luck to fit whatever circumstance the game creates for them. The stages, or "Episodes" start off simple but grow to quickly demand risk-management skills and careful planning ahead. Each character has its own set of deck elements, or equipment, that the player can create countless strategies from.  Enemies also have equipment, however the same enemies always have the same equipment. This makes the encounters more predictable and manageable as the players learns the strategies of each enemy, and how to  survive each encounter. 

Although the enemies and their decks never change, the episodes never get stale because each episode unlocks more difficult episodes that change a  variety of rules, at times even changing the rules of how enemies may act or effect the player. Some characters are certainly more fun to play than others, though no two characters feel the same to play as. Each character has its own set of episodes and rules/equipment regarding those episodes, but their mechanics never change very drastically. 

The presentation is easy on the eyes and well-animated, all the dialogue is clever and endearing and the music is catchy as all heck. The only time the game disappointed me was when there wasn't a reward for finishing all the challenges; every loss and win felt deserved - even if luck played a major role. If you want a game that consistently rewards clever decision making and can get past the mouse-only part as well as having lots of replayabillity with different strategies, this title will give you plenty of great fights and dice.

109469500.review:
Crazy fantastic value, and simply good fun, so long as you *can* tolerate some randomness and will not feel as if the universe is punishing you when you roll 6 1's in a row :-P

Core gameplay is very similar to deckbuilding card-battling roguelikes such as Slay the Spire. It has very distinct character of its own though, like a mash up of dice-placement + tableau building + roguelike.

A 'run' is much shorter than many similar games, perhaps taking 30 minutes total to reach the end-boss. Each run consists of 6 levels populated by combat encounters, health potions, equipment / upgrade shops and free equipment / upgrade nodes. There are no 'surprises', meaning that all the encounter types can be clearly seen and taken in a planned order.

Game is very puzzle-ley, but in a very open-ended way. Rather than there being a single 'solution' to any one encounter, level or the entire run, there are probably many. 

[b] What is awesome?  [/b]

Whilst the core gameplay is consistent, each of the six different characters (dice) play very, very differently, providing very different learning and challenge to enjoy.

For each of the six characters, there are then six run challenges / varieties, making for 36 total 'runs' to reach the true / end boss. Given strong variety this provides fantastic value for money, assuming you enjoy!

The big difference between characters and challenge types means that completing all 36 episodes, which took me about 50 hours, never really gets old.

No spoilers . . . the true end final boss provides a very clever, wonderfully designed combat encounter that rewards you for knowing the different enemy types and making clever, considered choices about how to play. If most combats are complexity 2-3 out of 5, the final fight is something more like a 4, and very satisfying.

[b] Caveats of note  [/b]

Like many similar games, the early parts of each run are very similar to one another, and you begin with a very limited set of options to choose between, which means sometimes you will just be 'administrating' rather than making choices. However, this is limited to the initial levels and given the very quick pacing, did not negatively impact my enjoyment.

Several enemies have particular weaknesses, for example to fire, frost, electricity, but it is very rare that you can do anything much to exploit this, since the number of opportunities to add / change equipment is limited. 

Unlike some similar games, the type of boss you will face at the end of the run is not known until you reach it, which means you cannot choose to build for it via your equipment and upgrade selections throughout the run, and you may sometimes therefore arrive with a set of very poor abilities for the fight

A consequence of the very different characters and variations is that you may bump up against a combination that feels frustrating / over-difficult. A funky thing is that the combination that does this for you may be one that other people breeze through first pass. My personal approach was to circle between the different characters rather than force myself to complete something I was struggling with.
