108847687.review:
Prepare to dice!

[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Dicey Dungeons is the latest game from Terry Cavanagh, developer of Super Hexagon and VVVVVV. The core gameplay involves building up decks of equipment to use in simple dungeons. On top of that core is vibrant art, funky music and short but clever writing.
You've probably heard of this game, it was popular when it came out a few years ago. I'm just here to sing its virtues, given that it recently took 40 hours from my life.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
While the gameplay focuses on building a deck of equipment which use dice to attack enemies, that core gameplay varies wildly depending on the character you play, and the scenario you play within.
For instance, the Warrior and Thief characters are pretty simple, they generally involve rolling and rerolling dice to hit desired numbers so that you can deal damage to your enemies using your equipment. The Thief has the added mechanic of stealing enemy equipment.
But the Inventor, on the other hand, is constantly compulsively destroying her own equipment to make gadgets (which perform a function without the roll of a dice), and the Witch uses dice rolls to both allocate spells to one of four spell slots, and to cast those spells (you have to balance between the two). Most people agree that the Witch is the most difficult to play.
Scenarios can range from changing your character's special ability, to imposing unique constraints on your dice, your health or your equipment. 
Each of the six characters has six scenarios to choose from, and, all told, you have to finish 30 scenarios in order to face the final boss. This is a little too long - the game doesn't really benefit from requiring so much gameplay, and unless you play the more difficult characters the challenge of each run is pretty straightforward. At the same time it was a challenge I committed myself to, and I can't deny that playing a run or two per day was fun.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The general plot for the game is that our main characters have made a deal with Lady Luck (a satan-like figure, in this game) to enter her dungeons for a chance to win a supernatural boon, such as the ability to go without sleep.
The story does not get much more complicated than that, and mostly lives in the background. There are occasional cutscenes with dialogue between your character and Lady Luck, and each enemy has a short bio unlocked by completing achievements. That said, in my opinion the writing was excellent, for being in the background. It added a good amount of flavor and basically never fell flat.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game is defined and saturated with very cute illustrations and animation done by Marlowe Dobbe. All the playable characters and enemies ooze personality with a glance. I could stare at them all day.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2729032633

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The soundtrack by Chipzel slaps. The funky bass was stuck in my head for a week. 
https://youtu.be/eKUAqS7mFrI

The music does get a little stale, considering the overlong playtime, as there are only a few of songs for combat. Occasionally I would lower the music volume and put on another Chipzel album to supplement it. Ultimately this was more due to the game being too long than anything to do with the music itself.

[h1]Technical Performance & Other[/h1]
I would sometimes have issues with selecting the wrong action when using my controller - it was a little too sensitive. My expectation is that there will be some mix ups if you play with a controller. They were annoying enough that I made sure to use a mouse on the final fight to avoid slip ups.

Since being released, many glitches and inconsistencies in the game have been fixed. yet there still is the occasional mismatch between expectation and reality, such as [spoiler]not being able to undo the choice to switch to another fighter in the final fight, so if you press the button by accident, tough luck. [/spoiler]

Finally, I just want to mention that developing content for the game isn't completely over. There is a mod community for new items and scenarios, and the dev(s) have also announced that there's more dicey dungeons content to come.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
Like a Rubix cube, this game does a lot with mechanics that are simple on their face. The game's other elements, like a funky chiptune soundtrack, and cute punky illustrations,
come together to finish the puzzle. If you're willing to sink a lot of time into it (or you're willing to put it down without finishing it), this game shouldn't disappoint.

108581076.review:
This game is very fun. I enjoy the roguelite features very much, and the different dice mechanics for each character make me want to play over and over again. There are 36 missions (6 per character), so you won't be frustrated for lack of content. There's also mods available for the game, with a notorious hardmode if you're interested.

My main gripe with the game is how often it crashes on my PC! It works fine on MacOS, but for some reason Windows can't handle it at times. This is mostly remedied by the nice autosave available, but it can be very demoralizing when your game crashes as your trying to strategize where to place your dice. This is the only game that does this on my Windows computer, so I'm not sure what the problem is. I've talked to the dev, and he said it's a graphics card issue, so uninstalling and reinstalling drivers might help if you run into this issue. However it did not help me.

If you like roguelite games with some clever rng and a very intuitive ui, this is the game for you. But you may run into some problems with the game crashing on Windows (to be fair: other friends who have played this have had no issues whatsover. Maybe I'm just unlucky). Hopefully the dev will provide a patch that fixes this in the future, because this game is absolutely fantastic otherwise.

107881671.review:
This game is great during your first hours of playtime, it's very addictive, the characters and monsters you meet/fight are interesting, the artstyle is decent and the music is so good that it will stay in your head. 

But once you want to try something harder and attempt the same character with added rules, the game becomes unbalanced and as a result, frustrating. There's no progression where you earn skill or think better as you die over and over again, allowing you to learn from your mistakes like other dungeon crawlers. You win if you have good RNG. If you don't and you know your run is going to fail, then you are still forced to continue playing until you die. 

They should've expanded the game by adding new floors and bosses rather than new gamemodes that are simply un-balanced, in which you have no real power over the game unless you have good RNG.

I kinda wish there was a little more enemy variety if this becomes a re-playable game for me. I have yet to check out the small modding community, but if they are good this will probably become one of my favourite timewaster games. 

I bought this for the price of a sandwich, but if you play even half the time i did, it's worth it the full price.

I've really only scraped the surface of the game but I just wanted to write down some of my thoughts about it. Personally I've been finding myself playing more indie games as of late due to many AAA games being criminally overpriced, filled with micro transactions, and usually end up unfinished at launch date. 

Dicey Dungeons are none of these things as you might guess. This game takes the form of dungeon crawler rougelike in which you choose certain cards and delve deeper. Although I haven't played Slay the Spire, many people regard it in a similar light for what I've seen. It's a pretty straightforward game, you basically build as you go along and most levels are relatively short. You have up to six characters available and they each have their own unique ability; each character also has a staggering six stories available which each increase in difficulty as you pillage and plunder. 

But as for my favorite thing about the game, I would definitely have to say is its presentation. It makes use of extremely fun art concept and binds together an addictive soundtrack with it. All the characters are pretty eccentric and has a good splash of humor mixed in. Pairing these elements together, you might even lose track of how long you've been playing once you get in the groove. Really though I think all of these elements just make a really enjoyable experience. For its price point, I would definitely recommend picking it up and giving it a go. You really can't go wrong with a quality indie game.

107542584.review:
This game was such a blast, with funny dialogue and lots of unique enemies, I didn't find myself becoming tired with the game once. Each dungeon is 6 floors, with harder enemies appearing on later floors, until you reach the 6th, where one of a handful of randomized bosses can appear. The enemies can appear on each floor are random, but third floor enemies generally won't be seen outside of the third floor, with some exceptions.

The classes of each dice was also really interesting to learn. Each die has a unique "class", like warrior or thief, and as a result of their class, they can result in wildly different playstyles on account of the unique mechanics each class has. As someone who has now collected every achievement in this game, the witch related achievements tended to be the hardest to do, since the witch can struggle with late game damage per turn compared to other classes. That being said, every single achievement is 100% within the realm of possibility for anyone to get, its just a matter of understanding which builds work best for certain classes. For instance, the thief is probably the only class with a viable poison build, as I've been able to stack over 50 poison damage on an enemy with the thief. Understanding how to build your dice as well as what changes you need to make to your builds as episodes change the mechanics are both incredibly important if you want to get through the dungeons. On top of all of that, the music in this game is a bop, so if for no other reason, I'd recommend you get it to listen to some tasty jams. Great game, couldn't recommend enough.

107246543.review:
The way the game works is that you play through 6 levels per episode with a boss on the 6th level. If you die, you have to start that episode over. You have the chance to pick up new abilities, change them out and upgrade them several times throughout each episode. Sometimes you're lucky, sometimes you're not, but you're usually able to find a way to make it work.
You don't lose hours if you fail an episode, you lose minutes, maybe 15-20 minutes max if you took your time and you died on the boss.
There are 6 different characters that increase in difficulty, and 6 episodes per character that also increase in difficulty.

Over-all the game is quite easy, but it does get more difficult as you advance to more episodes. When you advance to more episodes each run has different rules, basically modifiers for that run that makes it more difficult. Some are gimmicky and others are quite difficult, but it's obviously made to be beaten somehow, you have to get lucky sometimes but you also have to figure out how to beat an episode with certain modifiers, it's not always straight forward RNG, you also have to be smart with what equipment and upgrades you make.
If you play an episode with a modifier that reduces your health when you level up instead of increasing it, you have to think about what types of equipment you want to use and upgrade, obviously going full out damage on this episode wont work. Maybe the right mix of damage and healing/shielding and abilities that shock and lock dice of the enemy will tough.
So there is strategy involved in terms of basically figuring out what to do, it's not just straight-up RNG.

I would recommend this on sale. I wasn't a die-hard fan of it but I certainly enjoyed it when I was in the mood. My criticisms would be that it is, once you kinda [i]get it[/i], easy and boring in the long run. Nothing new really ever happens, the modifiers for each episode aren't enough to make it feel as fun over the entire period of the game for me.

But everything taken into account I recommend it on a sale for people who enjoy these games.
Something I'm also keeping in mind is that it is a low budget indie game, and for a low budget indie game it is quite impressive. Quite simply I find that it gets easy and boring over the long run, but for what it is, it isn't flat out bad.

107063780.review:
Dicey Dungeons is a unique take on the Slay-The-Spire formula that targets a much more casual audience and I found myself enjoying to a far higher extent. With shorter playthroughs, a simple core ruleset, and strategies that easier to create and maintain... its not for hardcore fans of the genre but the dabblers.

Unlike most of the genre, this isn't a deck building game but tableau builder. You get up to six action cards that are activated by using specific dice values/combinations. These actions are available every turn so there is no deck-thinning mechanics and leads to a more "consistent" experience. Each turn, you roll your dice and activate as many of your abilities as you can to defeat the enemy.

There's a good combination of a abilities that can either deal damage, apply status effects, and modify the dice. It's not overwhelming or particularly deep, but just enough to feel that you have some control. There are even cards that are effective for both high and low rolls allowing for some interesting builds. 

Obviously, as with any game with dice it is in part luck-based. You can mitigate the risks and boost your chances with good combos and support abilities but the dice can still screw you. But at 15-20 minutes per run it's not all that painful to restart.

The depth of the game comes from different characters that just the core rules. The Robot is a push-your-luck dice mechanic, the inventor constantly destroys your cards to create powerful "gadgets", the witch builds the tableau in-game etc. 

The only thing that really bothered me was the progression of the main game. In order to unlock the second episode for the warrior I needed to play the game as 5 different heroes rather than letting me use the character I'd mastered. I'd just started the game and it wasn't fun to have to play as a 5 star difficulty expert character in order to continue learning the rules.

Once you get the episodes unlocked, it's at least an interesting enough experience. Each one has slightly modified rulesets that will change the way you play or at least which strategies are effective. While I don't think I'll care enough to beat them all... it's likely to entertain me for a while.

Overall, I do highly recommend Dicey Dungeons to casual fans of the genre. It's lite and its random, and it's a lot of fun.

106418258.review:
Disclaimer: I'm a world record holder at Slay the Spire, with thousands of hours in this subgenre, so my opinion is heavily colored by that background.

Dicey Dungeons is a cute game which aims to expand upon the new roguelike deckbuilder subgenre that has exploded since the release of Slay the Spire in 2017. It's actually quite shocking how many notable titles have been released in the subgenre in such a short period of time: Inscryption, Roguebook, Monster Train, Griftlands, One Step from Eden, the list goes on. Clearly there is interest in this design space, and Dicey Dungeons does a lot of things to set itself apart, though ultimately it falls well short of being a game I can recommend to practically any type of gamer:

-Incredibly easy. Other than the Witch (more on her later), I was damn near perfect with every other character on my first go. This was while I was still reading the cards and learning game mechanics ... eventually I just blazed through the game with my brain turned off. Not a good feeling. I even started listening to podcasts while playing because it was so unengaging. I had a turn here or there that was interesting to its credit (usually with the Jester or Witch), but they're too far and few between. Oh and there's a level up system where you fully heal every few fights. Plus healing items are everywhere. So.... yeah you have a lot of leeway. Obviously this game was intended to be an easier, more approachable experience compared to the more hardcore variants in the subgenre, so maybe mileage might vary depending on your card game skill, but I expect anyone who has played Slay the Spire at all will be bored by the lack of challenge.

-Nearly no player choice. I guess there is technically pathing/nodes but not really; you never really have to deliberate about which way to go. Most turns don't have much agency; you just play the dice that were rolled. There's always only one enemy so you don't have to choose which one to target. Deckbuilding isn't generally presented as a multiple choice between cards, but rather take it or leave it, so you don't really have to do much thinking there either. Oh and most characters have an inventory system so if you mistakenly take a card, you can just unequip it from your deck .. making it even less punishing. Eeeeverything is streamlined, to the point that there's just nothing left. The whole fun of this subgenre is feeling like you control your own destiny, but the truth is in Dicey Dungeons, you just sort of take what the game gives you.

-Bland enemy design. Most enemies just deal damage or set a few status effects. That's it. You don't have to build your deck in certain ways to prepare for certain enemies; they all function the same.

-The individual character classes are unique and interesting but the basic strategy is the same. Just pick efficient cards and burn the enemy down. I found some cute combos but there aren't many deliberate synergies per se. A lot of cards are just deal X + one status effect. Not very compelling. Card balance is entirely out of whack; some cards are insultingly bad, and others are insane.

-The above factors culminate to a startling lack of depth. Which is a crippling problem in a roguelike, because they're naturally very repetitive. I muscled through for completions sake, but truth be told I think I got what I wanted out of the game in like ... 5-6 hours? But then there's another 25-30 if you want to complete everything and face the final boss (which I did). Most of this time you'll be bored, doing the same things. Every run feels the same, even between characters. These games are only fun with depth, but there's just not much here.

-I mentioned the Witch before, and I still can't decide if I love or hate her. She's the only one which had any challenge, but still lacked the agency to make her fun. Her core design is quite frustrating; she's insanely slow compared to the rest of the characters. While the other 5 easily deal 10-15 damage on turn 1 even early in their runs, the Witch can struggle to hit double digits at any point at all. Whereas the other characters spend 1 dice for most actions, the Witch has to spend 2 or more to do anything. And then her level ups make her choose between getting extra dice (which she really needs) and other upgrades (which she also really needs). Again, it's not that she's hard; the whole game is easy -- but moreso that she sticks out like a sore thumb. I think less experienced card gamers would struggle with her clunky mechanics, and experienced card gamers would be frustrated by her deficiencies without much agency to work around them.

-While the game has some charm, and is certainly cute, there are notable problems in the presentation department too. There are numerous UI elements missing so you often have incomplete information. Shops don't show you what the upgrade to a card is. You can't see if you'll level up after the fight from within a battle. You can't view the map while in battle. Lots of frustrating stuff like that. Also weird minor things like the volume lowers when you open up the options menu, but that's where you set your audio levels?? So when you go out of the options menu, it's now louder than you heard it while you were messing with your volume slider? Stuff like that makes me lose faith in the game's attention to detail and quality assurance; this is the easy stuff. Doesn't help that the game re-uses the same few audio clips and music tracks ad nauseum. I had to mute it and play my own music; something I never do. The writing is whatever too; there are a few cute lines, but for the most part it's very hokey and repetitive. Whatever. The art isn't bad at least, but certainly not exceptional.

I had a few cool moments with this game. There were a few standout moments. And hey, the final boss sequence was actually very cool. But most of it was a chore. A couple hours of intrigue doesn't forgive 30 hours of plodding boredom. Sad; I hope their next game is better. There is potential here.

Played this for a good few hours via Xbox Game Pass, and for under $4 on sale it was a no-brainer to pick up and own for if/when it's ever delisted from that service.

Absolutely infectious music and incredibly satisfying strategy that allows you to try and make the best of RNG. You may still get screwed over - as is the nature of RNG - but the strategic layer of if/how/when to use your dice gives you more of an edge than you might expect from a game that relies so heavily on random chance. Not to mention that each character plays almost bewilderingly differently, and as the levels progress there are gameplay curves thrown in that can be punishingly tough, but oh-so-satisfying to overcome. The amount of variety that Terry Cavanagh squeezed out of rolling virtual dice with these items and character classes is nothing short of impressive.

Easy recommendation for fans of rogue-lites and RNG-heavy deckbuilder type games. And even if this doesn't seem like the sort of game you'd enjoy, you should still at least look up the soundtrack on your music streaming platform of choice; the soundtrack simply slaps.

105815263.review:
(TL;DR at end of post)
I'm only focusing on the negative aspects that turned me off this game, and this review is subjective, so if any of the stuff I say matters to you then I would not recommend this game. Otherwise, give it a shot.

I don't think this game is worth its price - i got it at 66% off and I feel like that's a much fairer (or close to it) price. It just didn't satisfy me, I didn't feel like I developed any synergies or could even develop much in the way of deckbuilding. In my run I upgraded a couple cards but it didn't seem I could gain anything for them when I found better unupgraded cards, so it just felt like a waste. The trader only offered to trade one card, which felt a bit restrictive.

This is a good well-developed game, but it just doesn't fulfil what i like about rogue-like/lite games; developing a build for those great synergies rather than just try and try again until you beat the boss without much variation in your build from previous runs. There are no fail-safes in dicey dungeons that I am aware of for cases where you end up in a terrible position with your luck, making it feel pretty unforgiving.

There were also a couple minor bugs I found, although they weren't game-breaking at all, just confusing. If you hold onto your dice at the end of a battle, they stay visible on-screen until right after where you get your battle loot; this bug was accidental and I was confused as to what was happening for a moment. For the other bug, when you are in your backpack and switch between two items really quickly multiple times, they end up sharing the same spot, however this is only visual and fixes itself when you leave your backpack; this bug was half on purpose, as I just randomly decided to switch between my items really fast because ADHD lol.

TL;DR/Conclusion: Dicey dungeons is a good and well-developed game, however it just doesn't give me the right roguelike/lite fix I like; the deckbuilding element is minimal in terms of developing synergies and thus your separate runs will be fairly similar, and a lack of fail-safes makes getting into an unlucky situation very unforgiving. The bugs I experienced were very minor and purely visual, and not enough to change my opinion of the game much. I give Dicey Dungeons a [b]6.5/10[/b]. There are some areas for improvement, and I would not recommend this game to people with the same roguelike interests that I have.

105664112.review: Dicey Dungeons is an enjoyable rogue-lite where you advance through six short stages to beat a final boss, so a run does typically not take very long. There are six unlockable dice/characters with six variations of runs to beat. Coming from hundreds of hours of Slay the Spire before moving on to Dicey Dungeons, this offered significantly less of a challenge. Most of the stages were quite similar, so they were fairly easy to beat once one "gets" the quirks of the different characters. Some stages took a more significant leap away from the standard setup, and among those "Parallel Universe"-challenges where some of the more enjoyable runs. One aspect that I definitely disliked is that the final bosses are random to some extent, and there were runs where I was essentially invincible until I rolled an impossible to beat final boss. This was quite frustrating a couple of times, especially since I was very happy having achieved those builds right before the bosses. But overall it is much more forgiving than many other games in the genre. The final bosses are often not a big step up from the higher level enemies one fights right before. All-in-all, I'd say Dicey Dungeons is a good entry point to the genre but it does not quite rival the likes of FTL and Slay the Spire.

104860975.review:
This is a roguelite deckbuilder, with a few key differences:
[list]
[*] Your deck isn't drawn like a usual deck, you have a set amount of "cards" that you always have in play every turn (this can vary for other characters though)
[*] You don't draw a "hand" like usual - instead, you roll a fixed amount of dice, and you use the dice to activate/interact with your cards
[*] The roguelite aspects of this game are EXTREMELY lite.  Each floor is fairly simple, as are most enemies.  There is NO meta-progression which is a usual hallmark of roguelites.  Every run is self-contained, with the only account progression being unlocking new characters, and unlocking additional episodes for the characters which change the core rules for the run in some way.
[/list]

This game is amazing.  The characters are WILDLY unique, and play completely differently from each other.  The different unique abilities and cards of each character are awesome to learn and get used to.

The difficulty progression as you unlock the characters is very smooth.  Figuring out how to play each character is an absolute blast.

The strategy is not as deep as the current kings of deckbuilders, Slay the Spire and Monster Train.  Don't expect to sink 500+ hours into this game.  There is no equivalent of Ascension/Covenant difficulty in this game, once you beat every episode for every character the game will probably have extremely low replayability.  But this is fine, I'm ~20 hours in and I've only just unlocked the last character and beaten each character at least once.  I suspect completing all episodes for all characters and trying for 100% achievements will take 80 - 100 hours, maybe more.

Having said that, there is still a good deal of strategy to this game, especially for some of the more difficult characters.  Building your loadout to be versatile enough to make use of all types of rolls is crucial to winning.

The soundtrack is really good for this game, the battle theme hypes you up, and if you like the soundtrack to Terry Cavanaugh's other games like Super Hexagon, then the themes will feel very familiar

If you like deckbuilder games, this is 100% worth it for full price, but if you can get it on sale then it would be criminal to pass this one up.

102603424.review:
An excellent game!

Hidden behind the simplistic (and very charming!) aesthetic, there are surprisingly deep and complex systems at work, encouraging players to try all sorts of builds and strategies. Discovering powerful synergies is always hugely satisfying - and it's just as fun to blow away a boss as it is to scrape through by the skin of your teeth.

The 'game show' theme is whimsical and unique, just like the wide variety of cute characters/personalities you'll find waiting in the depths. What I really appreciate about [i]Dicey Dungeons[/i], though, is that it isn't afraid to shake up the formula. The Warrior and the Thief, for example, have playstyles that focus on different aspects of dice manipulation - but later characters run wild with their unique gimmicks and concepts, making the game feel completely different. The variation between chapters is also fantastic, with most offering new twists and caveats that force you to approach battles in different ways.

As a side note - if a fight isn't going your way, you can always try this:
- Exit to the title screen
- Reload your game
- Check your equipment (otherwise, you'll roll the same dice on the first turn)
- Try again!

Some may see this as cheating, but I enjoyed treating [i]Dungeons[/i] as more of a puzzle game than a strict roguelike... and without phenomenal luck, you'll be hard-pressed to get through some of the later chapters. Health management also plays a huge role: apples are a finite resource, so try to use them as little as possible (remember, you restore all health upon level-up). One spare apple on the map can often make or break a run.

All in all, I'd heavily recommend this game to anyone who's interested. I only wish I'd played it sooner!

102533113.review:
I've been behind this game when this game was only on Itch.io. This game for me just feels good, it's simplistic, has a feel good story and art style. I'm gonna spoil a lot in this review, but I'm not perfect at explaining certain characters fluently, so don't read my descriptions as a major guide.

This game has no real meta progression besides unlocking characters but unlocking characters is just an element of the story, this roguelike strangely also has no relic system like 99% of other roguelikes or roguelites too, there is an episode (6) which essentially does a relic system. I can see after reading negative steam reviews why people don't like the lack of relics, which seemingly leads to having no 'true' synergies or gameplay style changes.

This game is full on deckbuilding, you have cards (equipment), 6 spaces/slots to fit cards in. With two character's episode 1 there doesn't seem to be much 'skill' involved.  Speaking of characters, based on episode 1.

Warrior: You can reroll dice. Hit stuff with sword and sometimes gain a shield. Easy

Thief: You randomly take one your opponents equipment for a turn which you can use. Hit shit, with 1-3 rolls, manipulate dice or perhaps poison things to death. Easy but with some finesse 

Robot: Has a cpu mechanic which goes up with each time you 'roll' a dice, which you can then use those rolled dice into equipment e.g.
Roll a 5, cpu counter is 5/9. If you rolled a 4 on top you would gain a jackpot, Jackpot is a choice between 3 abilities. If the cpu meter goes over its number 10/9 for example everything errors out (unless mentioned otherwise) and you cannot use your remaining equipment for that turn. Very calculated character, easy-medium

Inventor: Has an inventing mechanic, after each fight you are presented with up to 3 randomly chosen pieces of equipment that you have equipped (won't be chosen if it's in your backpack) after choosing one your equipment to be essentially scrapped you gain a gadget for the next turn (effect being based on what you sacrificed) that you get to use once per turn for the next combat. IF you know how her mechanic works its medium, otherwise hard

Witch: You have spell slots, a cauldron & spells you have out, your equipment are put into spell slots, 1-6. If you put a 6 into your 'cauldron' if you have an equipment assigned to 6, you can choose to put down that equipment to use. Before a fight you can choose what equipment you preemptively have out already (since spells which you have put out don't stay out for the next combat). This character is easily the most complex and at times annoying as fuck to play with but winning feels good as this is the most skilled you get on a per-turn basis. Literally the hardest challenge in this game is beating episode 6 on hard mode with witch, not many have done so (according to achievements stats)

[spoiler]Jester: You have an actual deck of cards, at anytime you have 3 cards to use, as you use or discard them (for the turn) you get more from your deck until you cannot use any cards (dice don't fit, or for other reasons) or until you run out of cards in your deck for that turn, you have the ability to discard duplicates. This character's LIMIT BREAK ability makes it the most satisfying, fun and skilled to play (in terms of building a deck) Easy - medium (if you can't build a good deck[/spoiler]

Also every character has a limit break which can change from episode to episode. But generally each limit break is powerful and matches that characters playstyle in that episode.

If you ever feel like enjoying the game from a new perspective play some of the mods, some of the mods add a lot of content and have added plenty of hours for me so far. 

I love this game, this review is objectively kinda shit as it's not really telling you the pros or cons but I don't care, it's just a small description of my experience with the game, everything I've mentioned is about like 3-6 hours of the game. There's still 5 more episodes (6 if you count episode 6 hardmode as a new one) for 6 characters, for a total of 30 episodes. (35 if you include hardmode). There's even a big boss battle which nicely completes the story.

Do I recommend this? Fuck yeah, every game in history is repetitive and eventually loses replayability, this game is no Binding of Isaac but damn is it good. 10/10 (for me). Objectively I'd give it an 8/10 (lack of relics and for the witch which I hate and have a tiny itty bit of love for).

102265570.review:
Pros:
[list]
[*] Nice art style.
[*] Interesting game mechanics. You play as a dice, face enemies in a dungeon, roll dices and wield weapons against your enemies using the dices to fulfill the requirement of your equipments.
[*] Lovable characters, both the dices and the enemies.
[*] Enough variance between 6 playable characters and their episodes to keep you playing.
[*] Finding out synergies between equipments is a great pleasure.
[*] Episodes are independent and short (each takes around 30 minutes), which means even casual players with limited playtime can still enjoy its charm.
[*] The developer is very active and responsive, and really cares about the game. Two years after its release, this game still gets regular update (and a big free one is coming).
[*] Many amusing little details awaits you.
[*] Supports modding, which offers literally an infinity of possible extensions/modifications.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Annoying soundtrack and sound effects.
[*] Sometimes feels repetitive since you fight the same enemies over and over again.
[*] This game has a permadeath design. If you lose a fight, you have to begin the episode from scratch. However, unlike in Roguelite games, you get nothing from your previous failure except more experience on the game. You rebegin an episode with the same old weak character as your last run.
[*] Very serious RNG issues. Although one can make strategic choices (which equipment to equip/buy/upgrade, which dice to use on which weapon, which enemy to fight first, etc) to maximise the chance of survival, RNG factors are still overwhelming, especially for certain characters. On one hand, even if you do nothing wrong, you can still die because you don't get the rolls you need, or one of your enemies is rolling luckily enough to give you a final blow. On the other hand, when you happen to get a set of equipments with good synergy, you will be able to brute force through the whole episode without thinking too much.
[/list]

The RNG issues combined with the permadeath design makes the game unbearably frustrating when you play with difficult characters such as [spoiler]the witch[/spoiler], whose power relies heavily on your rolls. When you die a couple of times on the same level, the game becomes grinding and repetitive since each run of the same level only differs in the randomly chosen enemies and equipments.

Sure, permadeath can somehow be avoided if you quit the fight before death. The game only saves after each fight or each change of equipment or floor. So when you reload the episode, you can rebegin the same fight, or you can also pick another enemy, buy more equipments/health, or choose another set of equipments. However, when you put yourself into very unfavourable situation in which you can only make through a fight with lucky rolls and/or unlucky rolls from your enemy, then you still to have save scum a lot. To win a run or even the whole game like that, to paraphrase other reviewers, is like gambling on a coin flip: if it is head, you win; otherwise you lose. It still feels good to win, but hollowness follows afterward.

So, even though I have some fun playing through this game, I cannot recommend it unconditionally to other players. It does not mean this is a bad game. On the contrary, this game is well-made and you can really see how much energy and heart the dev has invested in it. My review serves only as a caveat. If you feel like you can handle/bear the RNG issues, then Dicey Dungeons would surely be a great game for you.

Information for completionists:
This game has in total [spoiler]46[/spoiler] episodes [spoiler](6 regular episode+1 hard mode bonus episode for each of the 6 playable characters, 1 finale, 3 Halloween special episodes)[/spoiler]. You will naturally get most of the achievements playing through all these episodes, which would take around 30 hours if you save scum to avoid death, significantly more if you don't. To get the rest, you have to replay some episodes to build your character with the achievement you want to unlock in mind. Several achievements might be grinding/risky to get.

102199225.review:
Dicey Dungeons is a charming deck-building rogue-lite developed by Terry Cavanagh, in which 6 adventurers who've been transformed into dice are put through their paces by a haughty game-show host. Well... it's more of an engine builder than a deck builder, but the latter is a subtype of the former, and one of the adventurers [i]plays[/i] like a deckbuilder, so....

In keeping with the dice theme, you'll roll some d6s each turn and plug them into what ever equipment/spells/skills you've accumulated during a playthrough. There's enough variation between the characters and their individual chapters to keep this from getting repetitive. The RNG can be a brutal at times (the Witch in particular can go from being a powerhouse to a wad of chewing gum and back depending on the spells you give her), but it works with the theme.

101818124.review:
So you want to play a game. A casual game. [i]Suuuuper[/i] casual that will in no way take up 70+hrs to play. So you pick up Dicey Dungeons. Here is the Bad and the Good.

The Bad:
1) Stupidly frustrating to work your way through all these minions just to lose right before the boss. Solution: don't lose. Also solution, [spoiler] If you lose a battle, escape back to the main page to try that battle again. Yes, it's cheap. Yes, it's not a saving grace. Yes, I'm not too proud to admit I abused it at times. Yes, I still lost. [/spoiler]
2) Yes, that's it. Just win and you will have fun.

The Good:
1) Different character types lead to different ways to play, though you have to play them all to some extent if you want to beat the game. Me likey variety.
2) There are Parallel Universe levels that switch up the play even more. I cannot state it more firmly, me likey variety.
3) The plot is loose, but cmon, you are playing as anthropomorphic dice. Get over it. Go play Skyrim if you want plot.
4) With item management, it can feel almost like a deck-building game, especially with one character (no spoilers on that one). Let's hear it again for those in the back, [i]me likey variety[/i].

Good luck, and may the odds be ever in your favor!

101733281.review:
It’s not necessary to log 100 hours on this game to write a reliable review for it. I’ve played it for over 8 hours and I love it and I know you will enjoy this game if you are like me and

A) you think it’s fun to play games of chance
B) you like dice games
C) you enjoy trading card games
D) always have a good time playing Yahtzee whether you win or lose

You will hate this game if:

A) you take losing to randomness really badly
B) you despise repeating steps several times to make progress through a game
C) you have ever had a tantrum losing at Yahtzee, Hearthstone, Blackjack, or Texas Hold’em, et. al.
D) you always play games with RNG-influenced outcomes thinking it is possible to control the outcome with the decisions you make only to discover that, if you lose, you feel like you wasted your time making those decisions because the computer didn’t roll what you needed
E) you have difficulty grasping satire and despise sarcasm 

The game for me is good fun. The “story” through which you progress: Lady Luck has you in her dungeon because you are eager to win but she’s eager to tease you into keep playing, never letting you escape from her dungeon, and to laugh at you as she deprives you of the luck you need to win and escape the dungeon with the prize of having what you most desire. No matter what class of “hero” you play, what you most desire is quite vapid. In fact, when you embark on your “quest” you are cast in a strange game show / reality TV show. The joke about luck even goes as far as always presenting you with a wheel of fortune spin you can never win at after you win a boss battle.

Basically, to beat the game, you must beat Lady Luck. This means you’re going to have to have to have more luck than luck itself. “Levels of difficulty” in this game mean, really, “levels of being less fortunate” as you progress through the game. This is what we call brutal satire, with a side of sarcasm. The rules of the game change as you progress. 

A “run” takes about 20 or 30 minutes to complete, so for me it’s fun when I need to do some casual game playing in a relatively short period of time.

Also, it’s so cool to have games like this available that don’t require buying packs of cards four times or more a year. This one is unique from the other wonderful Magic and Hearthstone alternatives because it is focused on rolling dice. I love Yahtzee and I see this as Yahtzee game with a narrative, hero powers, dynamic play conditions, and ever-changing rules of play.

It’s also fun to have to do battle with unusual “monsters” like a vacuum cleaner, an aurora, a boom box, or a snowman.

101719480.review:
This game is huge fun. It's cute, addictive and not that hard to learn. You'll clear 5 floors battling a few enemies on each one, find some loot and try to perfect the right combination of equipment to use. At the 6th floor you'll find a boss enemy. Once you defeat it, the game's over. You can complete a succesful run in about 30 minutes.

The game has great replay value: you have (at least?) 6 different 'classes', and each of these have 6 kind of game modes with (slightly) different rules. After 30 hours of play I'm not even close at completing them all.

You play a dice, and a lot of dice are rolled each fight, so the RNG is high. Some runs you'll find better equipment than other runs. Sometimes the RNG will screw you over. This might not be for everyone. However, by using the right mix of equipment you can really tone down the dependence of the right dice rolls during a fight. All in all I'd say the RNG adds fun to the game.

If I have to list any dislikes, it would be the mediocre music (which I usually just turn off anyways, so not really a problem) and the mouse pointer. It would be nice if the game didn't use the regular windows mouse pointer, which often vanishes in the heavily use of the colour white in this game, and instead would use a bigger, more obvious mouse pointer.

If you're on the fence: go buy this game! There's hours of fun to be had (if you don't mind RNG), even if you'll end up only playing a few of the classes a game modes.

Luck orientated game, you roll dice and you can influence the outcome.... a little. The characters are awesome, funny and narative changes depending where you have been. As you advance in the dungeon they get harder, but also you can get tougher.. or not. Its a game about luck and decision making, do you want to keep or take a sword. Will you regret it later? 

Each character has it's own game mechanic, so you can explore different ways of playing; and each dungeon has something extra. I really enjoy the variety of the gameplay and it doesn't take that long...to loose, you can leave anytime and come back to your game later, or try from a new beginning. 

Some characters can be very challenging to play with and it required many many replays to beat the boss.. or even reach the boss :D With .. well... Luck, they are all playable :D
 
Game is good for players who do not mind a lot of random (un)luck in their games, do enjoy a bit of deckbuilding and wish to have a small filler type of game in their library.

I'm really enjoying this game because it's quick to play and easy to understand. But in the later difficulties you will be at the mercy of RNG. Can't really call it a roguelike as I've seen some people say cuz you don't unlock anything to help mitigate the RNG, you just unlock new characters.

But it can be addicting regardless of the RNG, however sometimes it gets to me and I just alt-f4 lol. Look, you're buying a game called "Dicey Dungeons", if you thought it wasn't going to be RNG-based that's on you.

Edit - There are some people who think skill can win this game for you and the game isn't 100% RNG. I laughed so hard I burst my lungs and needed surgery. Please never listen to those people. This game IS RNG incarnate. You can't influence even close to enough about this game to help you against the RNG, at most you can save scum by alt-f4 and reloading game so you can start the battle again and maybe get better dice rolls lol.

Quick review:

Graphics: 8/10, very cute and cartoony, although that also means it's not everyone's cup of tea. If you like pastel colors and whimsical characters, it's great. I've heard people call it "tumblr-y," though. That's not really a downside for me, but I can see how it would be for other people. Up to personal taste, really.

Sound: 10/10, lovely music and the sound effects for attacks are actually really satisfying! I particularly like how the crowd will go "Ooooh!" when you land a lot of damage in one hit. The music also f*cking SLAPS.

Story: 7/10, the gimmick is that you're on a game show, each story segment is an "episode." It's not anything ground-breaking, but it's very charming, and the characters are well-written. There's also a couple nice twists, but why would I spoil that for you? Go play the game, ya dingus!

Gameplay: 6.5/10 Honestly, I feel like there isn't enough variety in the moves and attacks you can use each run. The cards are unique to each character, which is nice, but it also means that if you play the same character a few times in a row, you'll probably end up seeing the same cards too many times, and just relying on the same gimmicks. It's not [i]BAD[/i] though, I think it's meant to encourage trying out new characters. And I will say that the Robot has a VERY cool gimmick.

Overall: 8/10 Not a very in-depth or hardcore Rogue-like (Rogue-lite? there's no permanent upgrades besides unlocking characters). But if you need a more casual Rogue-whatever game to relax to, it's worth the price. Especially on sale. If Rogue-lites like Slay the Spire and Enter the Gungeon are steak dinners, then Dicey Duneons is a warm, home-cooked meal. Not as expensive or as flashy, but will still make you feel full and warm after trying it. :)

101488050.review:
Thought I beat the game on the first try, and was worried that it was too easy. Then I was hit with the "Congratulations, now you can move on to the next 35 episodes with increasing difficulty!" So I definitely will not be beating the game anytime soon. If you are familiar with roguelike deckbuilder type games, I'm sure you will will enjoy this one. 

I can already see how RNG could hurt a run or get annoying, but there are equipment cards that are specifically used for reducing RNG dependency, so if other reviews are scaring you (about how bad the RNG is) I wouldn't worry *too* much. All roguelike games include some form of RNG, and it does have a larger effect on games like this where it isn't action based (like Isaac or Hades). But when a game is literally about "rolling the dice" I think it isn't too detrimental to the experience, especially with the inclusion of cards that can reroll/change your dice. There are a lot of interesting mechanics going on in this game. The inventory/equipment management and the card upgrades are really cool and I think if this game looks like something you would enjoy, you probably will. I got it on sale for ~$5.00 US and I think that is an excellent price for the amount of content you get.

101443765.review:
Absolutely amazing little game. Can't recommend enough. I bought this in the sale for £3 and it surpasses most £20+ games I've gotten. 

Was a little hesitant at first because I tend to find rogue deck builder games wear old real quick and get repetitive within a few hours, but this game manages to stay fresh with every new character and episode. For me the thing that sets it apart is the fact that each character isn't just "kill thing but with slightly different cards", but instead their special moves change everything about your play style entirely to the extent it nearly feels like a different game each time you start on a new character. Each special ability forces your focus to change on different aspects of the game, so while the warrior character feels like your bog standard deck builder of hit a thing until it dies, you'll get something like the robot who's rolling concept is so different that you're playing black jack while trying to balance what moves to do when without going bust. The inventor's special forces you to constantly rotate through your weapons so you can never get comfortable with one set. Or a later character where you're juggling cards to get matching pairs for strong combos.

I've played through every episode with virtually every character at this point and always find the episodes to be a fun challenge which force you out of your comfort zone and get you thinking of different ways to play the characters. For the negative reviews saying the challenges are too difficult, or that the game is entirely RNG based, I can only assume they haven't quite understood the need for completely changing your playstyle each episode. You can't brute force your way through the challenges, you need to plan ahead and understand what's being asked of you. And while there's RNG in the dice rolls, naturally, most times there's a lot of freedom for a character to be effective no matter what you roll, so with the right planning you'll be able to adapt and build to win whether you roll a 1 or a 6. I found nearly every episode easy enough to clear after 2 or 3 attempts, and those first failures weren't RNG or 'bad rolls', just learning the new format of the challenge and how it interacts with everything.

tl;dr: Buy the game, it's like a rogue deckbuilder but better, and with far less RNG than the dice might make you believe.

100716061.review:
Dicey Dungeons is an interesting take on something like the deckbuilding roguelike format. The way that it works is that each turn you roll a pool of dice, and then you can spend individual dice on a collection of abilities, each of which has different rules about what numbers it can accept and how they'll affect the ability's results, and some abilities will also change the faces of your dice.
The good:
- Interesting core mechanic and the content feels well made and well suited to the mechanics
- Characters and story missions with extra rules give the game some decent replayability that feels a bit less divorced from normal gameplay than stuff like the custom mode in Slay the Spire
- Fun strategy both during and between fights
- Good writing and music

The bad:
- Sometimes you'll just get screwed over by more bad RNG than any amount of strategy can compensate for
- Difficulty in general can be a bit wonky
- The animations are pretty basic in a way that throws off the feel of the game. I genuinely think that it would feel like you're doing twice as much damage if the enemies actually had proper flinch animations. I don't complain about graphics not being ornate for its own sake, but this is a case where better graphics really would have improved the experience.

100011938.review:
It is only a matter of time before you will ragequit in frustration. Trust me, this game will make you rage. This is your last warning. I am trying to save you time, money and sanity. If you don't believe me, just remember "Witch 4". You will be back and I will accept your apology.

But then why are there so many glowing reviews?
That's because Dicey Dungeons starts out as a great game, but the deeper you go, the worse and worse the game gets.

Dicey Dungeons is separated into different episodes.
The first episode is great: standard rules, lots of items to pick from, you build your character and fight a boss. You won't lose once you learn the mechanics and which items are good. 
The later episodes have different rules and some completely change every aspect of the game - this is great.

But here's the problem:
-You starting equipment is always the same and it's usually terrible.
-Equipment drops and shops have the same items every run, only a few drops and shops have random items.
-The pool of items to pick from is drastically reduced.

So basically all of your choices and ability to build your character and all of the fun is gone.
What's left? RNG, RNG and more RNG.

These later episodes are not hard or difficult or require any thinking, just luck.
I would cruise through 8 episodes without losing and then bam, lose 3 times in a row early on.
I would play slowly and carefully and every move was perfect, but it did not matter. Once RNG gave me a certain item, boom the episode is easy. 

In other card battlers there are abilities or cards that can get you out of a jam, but in Dicey Dungeons, you sit there and say "This run is a win unless the enemy gets 3 perfect rolls, then the run is over". This is the part you will rage.

In the forums the most common thread is complaints about the RNG. And that makes sense because for most of Dicey Dungeons, you will be staring at the dice rolls and thinking, I just rolled 7 dice and not a single 6 showed up, what is the probability of that? I'm not one of the people who think the RNG is unfair against the player, it is simply a matter that there are so many RNG rolls in a run, the chance of getting an unlucky run ending streak is higher than you would expect.

99337578.review:
DD is a dice-based dungeon-crawler rouge-like. On a run, you select one of six characters, and one of six (progressively unlockable) "episodes" for your given run. Each episode features a different theme, with a different rule-set, sometimes vastly so. There is a game-ending boss after completing all 36 episodes (each of which feature a "mini-boss"), as well as some achievements to aim for. 

Pros:
[list]
[*] Extremely diverse cast of main six characters, who for the most part play completely differently.
[*] Nice range of equipment that may be found on a given run. The diversity of equipment across all characters is actually quite impressive.
[*] The episodes (i.e. different rule-sets) within a character are very creative at times.
[*] Really nice array of mechanics, as applied to a dice game, on both the equipment and the status effects (freezing, burning, silence, weaken, etc.).
[/list]


YMMV:
[list]
[*] I didn't care much for the art, but it seemed to fit with the overall feel of the game.
[*] The game-show theme and unique dialogue were funny at first, but it seems like the devs ran out of clever material and sort of gave up. Making me watch them spin the wheel 36 times was pointless. 
[*] Make no mistake, some of these episodes are really hard. I required a dozen or so tries on some of them. This is particularly the case for the Inventor and the Witch. Often you will straight up lose to RNG, either due to your rolls, enemy rolls, bad equipment pulls, or in the bonus round on bad floor-rules. 
[*] I found the Inventor, who is forced to lose equipment after each turn unfun. It didn't help that this was also one of the hardest characters (aside from the Witch, which I liked the most), thus forcing me to play it the most. The decision to only allow the player to select from three pieces of equipment, was a poor one IMO.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] AFAIK there is no way to check the moves of enemies prior to fighting them, either via right click or hover or a beastiary. This QoL feature is expected in games like this.
[*] As with all enemies in the dungeon, the final mini-boss is random. If that boss happens to hard-counter your build, you will lose. It would be nice to know who the mini-boss is prior to the final floor.
[/list]

Summary: My first few runs of DD were uninspired and I was disappointed. However, I stuck with it and was pleasantly surprised with what the devs had in store for me. I probably won't ever play again, having completed all 36 episodes (and the bonus round on hard with all six characters), but I surely got my money's worth. If you can stomach the slightly elevated level of RNG present, then this is a game you should purchase.

Overall: 8.5/10

Terry Cavanagh's take on a roguelike game. It's funny to see how different Dicey Dungeons's cartoonish art (art by Marlowe Dobbe) is compared to Cavanagh's other games like VVVVVV or Super Hexagon. I dig it.

As the title implies, in Dicey Dungeons you venture into a 5 floor dungeon rolling dices. Those rolls will determine the damage and/or effects of your weapons against quirky and charismatic enemies. If you kill the dungeon boss at the end, you unlock new classes and challenges. If you don't, each run is short enough that you will probably give it another go. 

As I'm writing this I just want to pick it up and play it again. You should do that too.

99139340.review:
A simple premise with surprisingly perplexing complications. Each run is it's own puzzle, with altered rules for the scenario you've picked tailored to the class you are playing and then the specifics of the dungeon procedurally generated. The art is adorable, reminiscent of the tongue-in-cheek-iness of the Powder Puff Girls or Samurai Jack. The music is a good fit, frenetic and game show appropriate, fitting the silly premise. This is really well made, well thought out, and well executed. Portions of it can be devilishly hard, but as a rogue lite you can always hope better the next time. I love the achievement system that unlocks ridiculous character bios of the NPCs you're fighting.

If you liked Slay The Spire, you will likely love this. Great game, with surprisingly more depth than I was expecting.
